	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Catholic Church</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"><span class="mw-redirectedfrom">&#160;&#160;(Redirected from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholics&amp;redirect=no" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholics">Roman Catholics</a>)</span></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Catholic" and "Catholicism" redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Catholic Church (disambiguation)">Catholic Church (disambiguation)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Catholic (disambiguation)">Catholic (disambiguation)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Roman Catholic Church (disambiguation)">Roman Catholic Church (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Largest Christian church, led by the Bishop of Rome</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">


</p>

</div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;border-top:1px solid #aaa;border-bottom:1px solid #aaa;">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="32" height="24" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/48px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/64px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;padding-right:0.2em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template:Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template talk:Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Church_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Catholic Church</b>, also known as the <b>Roman Catholic Church</b>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations_by_number_of_members" title="List of Christian denominations by number of members">largest Christian church</a>, with approximately 1.3&#160;billion <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">baptised</a> Catholics worldwide as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-Annuario_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annuario-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> As the world's oldest and largest continuously functioning international institution,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> it has played a prominent role in the history and development of <a href="/wiki/Western_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Western civilisation">Western civilisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-O&#39;CollinsPref_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-O&#39;CollinsPref-6">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> The church is <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">headed</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Bishop of Rome</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a>. Its central administration, the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, is in the <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Enclave" class="mw-redirect" title="Enclave">enclave</a> within the city of Rome in Italy.
</p><p>The Christian beliefs of <b>Catholicism</b> are based on the <a href="/wiki/Nicene_Creed" title="Nicene Creed">Nicene Creed</a>. The Catholic Church teaches that it is the <a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">One, Holy, Catholic and Apostolic</a> church founded by <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Jesus Christ</a> in his <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup> that its <a href="/wiki/Bishop_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop (Catholic Church)">bishops</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">successors</a> of Christ's <a href="/wiki/Apostle_(Christian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostle (Christian)">apostles</a>, and that the <a href="/wiki/Papal_primacy" title="Papal primacy">pope is the successor</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a> upon whom <a href="/wiki/Primacy_of_Peter" title="Primacy of Peter">primacy</a> was conferred by <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus Christ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> It maintains that it practises the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">original Christian faith</a>, reserving <a href="/wiki/Infallibility_of_the_Church" title="Infallibility of the Church">infallibility</a>, passed down by <a href="/wiki/Sacred_tradition" title="Sacred tradition">sacred tradition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CCC_890_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_890-13">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>, the twenty-three <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute_(Catholic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious institute (Catholic)">institutes</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mendicant_orders" title="Mendicant orders">mendicant orders</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enclosed_religious_orders" title="Enclosed religious orders">enclosed monastic orders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_orders" class="mw-redirect" title="Third orders">third orders</a> reflect a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">variety</a> of <a href="/wiki/Theology" title="Theology">theological</a> and spiritual emphases in the church.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gunton2_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton2-15">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Of its <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">seven sacraments</a> the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist</a> is the principal one, celebrated <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgy" title="Catholic liturgy">liturgically</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Mass</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> The church teaches that through <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecration</a> by a <a href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Priesthood (Catholic Church)">priest</a> the sacrificial <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_bread" title="Sacramental bread">bread</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_wine" title="Sacramental wine">wine</a> <a href="/wiki/Transubstantiation" title="Transubstantiation">become the body and blood of Christ</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Virgin Mary</a> is <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">venerated</a> in the Catholic Church as <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">Mother of God</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Heaven" title="Queen of Heaven">Queen of Heaven</a>, honoured in <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_Catholic_Church#Dogmatic_teachings" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariology of the Catholic Church">dogmas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marian_devotions" title="Marian devotions">devotions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-marian_dogmas_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marian_dogmas-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> Its teaching includes <a href="/wiki/Divine_Mercy" title="Divine Mercy">Divine Mercy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sanctification" title="Sanctification">sanctification</a> through faith and <a href="/wiki/Evangelisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelisation">evangelisation</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">Gospel</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a>, which emphasises voluntary support for the sick, the poor, and the afflicted through the <a href="/wiki/Works_of_mercy" title="Works of mercy">corporal and spiritual works of mercy</a>. The Catholic Church is the largest non-government provider of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_education" title="Catholic education">education</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">health care</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Catholic Church has influenced <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Western art">art</a>, and science. Catholics live all over the world through <a href="/wiki/Catholic_missions" title="Catholic missions">missions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity" title="Conversion to Christianity">conversions</a>. Since the 20th century the majority reside in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_hemisphere" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern hemisphere">southern hemisphere</a> due to <a href="/wiki/Postchristianity" title="Postchristianity">secularisation</a> in Europe, and increased <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">persecution</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.
</p><p>The Catholic Church shared <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> until the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> in 1054, disputing particularly the <a href="/wiki/Papal_primacy" title="Papal primacy">authority of the Pope</a>. Before the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> in AD 431 the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a> also shared in this communion, as did the <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Oriental Orthodox churches">Oriental Orthodox churches</a> before the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> in AD 451, all separating primarily over <a href="/wiki/Chalcedonian_Definition" title="Chalcedonian Definition">differences in</a> <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christology</a>.  In the 14th century, the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Counter_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Counter Reformation">Counter Reformation</a> lead to further divisions with historic consequences.  
</p><p>From the late 20th century, the Catholic Church has received <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Criticism of the Catholic Church">criticism</a> from some for its <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology_of_sexuality" title="Catholic theology of sexuality">teaching on sexuality</a>, its inability to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_doctrine_on_the_ordination_of_women" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church doctrine on the ordination of women">ordain women</a>, as well as the handling of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_cases" title="Catholic Church sexual abuse cases">sexual abuse cases</a> involving clergy.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_(term)" title="Catholic (term)">Catholic (term)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_(term)" title="Roman Catholic (term)">Roman Catholic (term)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ignatius_of_Antiochie,_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_(17th_c.,_Pushkin_museum).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/220px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="292" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/330px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/440px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1129" data-file-height="1500" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ignatius_of_Antiochie,_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_(17th_c.,_Pushkin_museum).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first use of the term "Catholic Church" (literally meaning "universal church") was by the <a href="/wiki/Church_father" class="mw-redirect" title="Church father">church father</a> Saint <a href="/wiki/Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Ignatius of Antioch">Ignatius of Antioch</a> in his <i><a href="/wiki/Letter_to_the_Smyrnaeans" class="mw-redirect" title="Letter to the Smyrnaeans">Letter to the Smyrnaeans</a></i> (circa 110&#160;AD).<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> Ignatius of Antioch is also attributed the earliest recorded use of the term "Christianity" (Greek: <span lang="el">Χριστιανισμός</span>) <span class="languageicon">(in Catalan)</span> 100&#160;A.D.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElwellComfort2001266,_828_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElwellComfort2001266,_828-20">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> He died in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, with his <a href="/wiki/Relic" title="Relic">relics</a> located in the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Clemente_al_Laterano" class="mw-redirect" title="Basilica of San Clemente al Laterano">Basilica of San Clemente al Laterano</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Catholic (from <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">καθολικός</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>:&#160;</small><i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language romanization">katholikos</i>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>&#160;</small>&#39;universal&#39;) was first used to describe the church in the early 2nd century.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The first known use of the phrase "the catholic church" (<span lang="el" title="Greek language text">καθολικὴ ἐκκλησία</span> <i>he katholike ekklesia</i>) occurred in the letter written about 110 AD from <a href="/wiki/Saint_Ignatius_of_Antioch" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Ignatius of Antioch">Saint Ignatius of Antioch</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrnaeans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;note 2&#93;</a></sup> In the <i>Catechetical Lectures</i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;350</span>) of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Cyril_of_Jerusalem" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Cyril of Jerusalem">Saint Cyril of Jerusalem</a>, the name "Catholic Church" was used to distinguish it from other groups that also called themselves "the church".<sup id="cite_ref-CathEnc1910_Catholic_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CathEnc1910_Catholic-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup> The "Catholic" notion was further stressed in the edict <i><a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Thessalonica" title="Edict of Thessalonica">De fide Catolica</a></i> issued 380 by <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a>, the last emperor to rule over both the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">eastern</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">western</a> halves of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, when establishing the <a href="/wiki/State_church_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="State church of the Roman Empire">state church of the Roman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> of 1054, the <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Church">Eastern Church</a> has taken the adjective "Orthodox" as its distinctive epithet (however, its official name continues to be the "Orthodox Catholic Church"<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup>) and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Church">Western Church</a> in communion with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> has similarly taken "Catholic", keeping that description also after the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> of the 16th century, when those who ceased to be in communion became known as "Protestants".<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-McBrien_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McBrien-28">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>While the "Roman Church" has been used to describe the pope's <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Diocese of Rome</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">Fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> and into the <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">Early Middle Ages</a> (6th–10th century), the "Roman Catholic Church" has been applied to the whole church in English language since the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> in the late 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> "Roman Catholic" has occasionally appeared also in documents produced both by the Holy See,<sup id="cite_ref-RCHolySeeR_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RCHolySeeR-30">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> notably applied to certain national <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_conference" title="Episcopal conference">episcopal conferences</a>, and local dioceses.<sup id="cite_ref-RCbishop_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RCbishop-31">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The name "Catholic Church" for the whole church is used in the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> (1990) and the <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canon_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Code of Canon Law">Code of Canon Law</a> (1983). The names "Catholic Church" and "Roman Church" are also used in the documents of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> (1962–1965),<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> (1869–1870),<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> (1545–1563),<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> and numerous other official documents.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Organisation">Organisation</span></h2>
<p><span id="Organization_and_demographics"></span><span id="Organisation_and_demographics"></span>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">Hierarchy of the Catholic Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/220px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="298" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/330px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/440px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="815" data-file-height="1105" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and whatever you bind on Earth shall be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on Earth shall be loosed in heaven." Jesus to Peter in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.esv.org/Matthew+16:19">16:19</a><p>The crossed gold and silver keys of the Holy See symbolise the keys of <a href="/wiki/Simon_Peter" class="mw-redirect" title="Simon Peter">Simon Peter</a>, representing the power of the papal office to loose and bind. The triple crown <a href="/wiki/Papal_tiara" title="Papal tiara">papal tiara</a> symbolises the triple power of the Pope as "father of kings", "governor of the world" and "Vicar of Christ". The gold cross on a <a href="/wiki/Monde_(crown)" class="mw-redirect" title="Monde (crown)">monde</a> (<a href="/wiki/Globe" title="Globe">globe</a>) surmounting the tiara symbolises the sovereignty of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>.</p></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church follows an <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_polity" title="Episcopal polity">episcopal polity</a>, led by bishops who have received the sacrament of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church#Sacraments_at_the_service_of_communion" title="Catholic Church">Holy Orders</a> who are given formal <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_jurisdiction" title="Ecclesiastical jurisdiction">jurisdictions</a> of governance within the church.<sup id="cite_ref-CCC880_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCC880-37">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CEHierarchy_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CEHierarchy-38">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> There are three levels of clergy, the episcopate, composed of bishops who hold jurisdiction over a geographic area called a <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">diocese</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchy</a>; the presbyterate, composed of priests ordained by bishops and who work in local diocese or religious orders; and the diaconate, composed of deacons who assist bishops and priests in a variety of ministerial roles. Ultimately leading the entire Catholic Church is the Bishop of Rome, commonly called the pope, whose jurisdiction is called the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>. In parallel to the diocesan structure are a variety of <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute_(Catholic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious institute (Catholic)">religious institutes</a> that function autonomously, often subject only to the authority of the pope, though sometimes subject to the local bishop. Most religious institutes only have male or female members but some have both. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_laity" title="Catholic laity">lay members</a> aid many liturgical functions during worship services.
</p>
<h3><span id="Holy_See.2C_papacy.2C_Roman_Curia.2C_and_College_of_Cardinals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_See,_papacy,_Roman_Curia,_and_College_of_Cardinals">Holy See, papacy, Roman Curia, and College of Cardinals</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_popes" title="List of popes">List of popes</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_(14036966125).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/220px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="207" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/330px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/440px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2913" data-file-height="2746" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_(14036966125).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Francis</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_popes" title="List of popes">266th</a> and current <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> of the Catholic Church, a <a href="/wiki/Courtesy_title" title="Courtesy title">title</a> he holds <i><a href="/wiki/Ex_officio" class="mw-redirect" title="Ex officio">ex officio</a></i> as <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Bishop of Rome</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereigns_of_Vatican_City_State" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereigns of Vatican City State">sovereign</a> of <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>. He was elected in the <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave,_2013" class="mw-redirect" title="Papal conclave, 2013">papal conclave, 2013</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg/220px-Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg/330px-Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg/440px-Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7507" data-file-height="6805" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Archbasilica_of_St._John_Lateran_HD.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Archbasilica_of_Saint_John_Lateran" title="Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran">Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral" title="Cathedral">cathedral</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Diocese of Rome</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">hierarchy of the Catholic Church</a> is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Bishop of Rome</a>, known as the pope (<a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">papa</i>; "father"), who is the leader of the worldwide Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-section880_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-section880-39">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> The current pope, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Francis</a>, was elected on 13 March 2013 by <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave,_2013" class="mw-redirect" title="Papal conclave, 2013">papal conclave</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-habemus_papem_2013_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-habemus_papem_2013-40">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="vertical-navbox vcard" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding:0.4em 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Scale_of_justice,_canon_law.svg" class="image" title="Scale of justice"><img alt="Scale of justice" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/100px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="102" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/150px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/200px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="178" data-file-height="182" /></a></td></tr><tr><td style="padding-top:0.2em;line-height:1.2em">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Category:Canon law of the Catholic Church">a series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;padding-top:0;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em"><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law of the<br />Catholic Church</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left"><i>Jus vigens</i> (current law)</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:left">

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Pastor_bonus" title="Pastor bonus">Pastor bonus</a></i>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Pontificalis_Domus" title="Pontificalis Domus">Pontificalis Domus</a></i></li></ul></li>

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left"><a href="/wiki/Legal_history_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Legal history of the Catholic Church">Legal history</a></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:left"><i><b><a href="/wiki/Jus_antiquum" title="Jus antiquum">Jus antiquum</a></b></i> (c. 33-1140)

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Donation_of_Constantine" title="Donation of Constantine">Donation of Constantine</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gregorian_Reform" title="Gregorian Reform">Gregorian Reform</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Investiture_Controversy" title="Investiture Controversy">Lay investiture controversy</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Dictatus_papae" title="Dictatus papae">Dictatus papae</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Libertas_ecclesiae" title="Libertas ecclesiae">Libertas ecclesiae</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Plenitudo_potestatis" title="Plenitudo potestatis">Plenitudo potestatis</a></i></li></ul></li></ul>
<p><i><b>Jus novum</b></i> (c. 1140-1563)
</p>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Corpus_Juris_Canonici" title="Corpus Juris Canonici">Corpus Juris Canonici</a></i>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Decretum_Gratiani" title="Decretum Gratiani">Decretum Gratiani</a></i>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Decretist" title="Decretist">Decretist</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Canon_Episcopi" title="Canon Episcopi">Canon Episcopi</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Margaritae" title="Margaritae">Margaritae</a></i></li></ul></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Jus_commune" title="Jus commune">Jus commune</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Decretales_Gregorii_IX" title="Decretales Gregorii IX">Decretals of Gregory IX</a></i>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Decretalist" title="Decretalist">Decretalist</a></li></ul></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Regul%C3%A6_Juris" title="Regulæ Juris">Regulæ Juris</a></i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Extravagantes" title="Extravagantes">Extravagantes</a></i></li>

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">Temporal goods (property)</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:left">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Benefice" title="Benefice">Benefice</a></li>

</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">Law of <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_life" title="Consecrated life">consecrated life</a></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;text-align:left">

<p><a href="/wiki/Society_of_apostolic_life" title="Society of apostolic life">Society of apostolic life</a>
</p>
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Decretum_laudis" title="Decretum laudis">Decretum laudis</a></i></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_canon_law" title="Template:Catholic canon law"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_canon_law" title="Template talk:Catholic canon law"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_canon_law&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The office of the pope is known as the <i>papacy</i>. The Catholic Church holds that Christ instituted the papacy upon giving the <a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">keys of Heaven</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>. His <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_jurisdiction" title="Ecclesiastical jurisdiction">ecclesiastical jurisdiction</a> is called the "<a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>" (<i>Sancta Sedes</i> in Latin), or the "<a href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic See">Apostolic See</a>" (meaning the see of the apostle Peter).<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> Directly serving the pope is the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a>, the central governing body that administers the day-to-day business of the Catholic Church.
</p><p>The pope is also <a href="/wiki/List_of_Sovereigns_of_the_Vatican_City_State" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Sovereigns of the Vatican City State">Sovereign</a> of <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> a small <a href="/wiki/City-state" title="City-state">city-state</a> entirely <a href="/wiki/Enclave_and_exclave" title="Enclave and exclave">enclaved</a> within the city of Rome, which is an entity distinct from the Holy See. It is as head of the Holy See, not as head of Vatican City State, that the pope receives ambassadors of states and sends them his own diplomatic representatives.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> The Holy See also confers <a href="/wiki/Orders,_decorations,_and_medals_of_the_Holy_See" title="Orders, decorations, and medals of the Holy See">orders, decorations and medals</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Orders_of_chivalry" class="mw-redirect" title="Orders of chivalry">orders of chivalry</a> originating from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>.
</p><p>While the famous <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Peter&#39;s Basilica">Saint Peter's Basilica</a> is located in Vatican City, above the traditional site of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_tomb" title="Saint Peter&#39;s tomb">Saint Peter's tomb</a>, the papal <a href="/wiki/Cathedral" title="Cathedral">cathedral</a> for the Diocese of Rome is the <a href="/wiki/Archbasilica_of_Saint_John_Lateran" title="Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran">Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran</a>, located within the city of Rome, though enjoying <a href="/wiki/Extraterritorial" class="mw-redirect" title="Extraterritorial">extraterritorial</a> privileges accredited to the Holy See.
</p><p>The position of <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholicism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardinal (Catholicism)">cardinal</a> is a rank of honour bestowed by popes on certain clergy, such as leaders within the Roman Curia, bishops serving in major cities and distinguished theologians. For advice and assistance in governing, the pope may turn to the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McDonough227_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McDonough227-45">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the death or resignation of a pope,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;note 5&#93;</a></sup> members of the College of Cardinals who are under age 80 act as an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_college" title="Electoral college">electoral college</a>, meeting in a <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">papal conclave</a> to elect a successor.<sup id="cite_ref-duffy416_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-duffy416-48">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> Although the conclave may elect any male Catholic as pope, since 1389 only cardinals have been elected.<sup id="cite_ref-duffy417and18_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-duffy417and18-49">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Canon_law">Canon law</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church#Liturgy" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church §&#160;Liturgy</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law</a> (<a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">jus canonicum</i>)<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> is the <a href="/wiki/Legal_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal system">system</a> of <a href="/wiki/Law" title="Law">laws</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">legal principles</a> made and enforced by the <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">hierarchical authorities</a> of the Catholic Church to regulate its external organization and government and to order and direct the activities of Catholics toward the mission of the church.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> The canon law of the Latin Church was the first modern Western <a href="/wiki/Legal_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal system">legal system</a><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> and is the oldest continuously functioning legal system in the West,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> while the distinctive traditions of <a href="/wiki/Oriental_canon_law" title="Oriental canon law">Oriental canon law</a> govern the 23 <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic</a> <a href="/wiki/Particular_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Particular church">particular churches</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a>.</i>
</p><p>Positive ecclesiastical laws, based directly or indirectly upon immutable divine law or <a href="/wiki/Natural_law" title="Natural law">natural law</a>, derive formal authority in the case of universal laws from <a href="/wiki/Promulgation_(canon_law)" title="Promulgation (canon law)">promulgation</a> by the supreme legislator—the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Pontiff" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Pontiff">Supreme Pontiff</a>—who possesses the totality of legislative, executive and judicial power in his person,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> while particular laws derive formal authority from promulgation by a legislator inferior to the supreme legislator, whether an ordinary or a delegated legislator. The actual subject material of the canons is not just doctrinal or moral in nature, but all-encompassing of the human condition. It has all the ordinary elements of a mature legal system:<sup id="cite_ref-clinfocat_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-clinfocat-56">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> laws, courts, lawyers, judges,<sup id="cite_ref-clinfocat_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-clinfocat-56">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> a fully articulated <a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">legal code</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a><sup id="cite_ref-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49-57">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> as well as a <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">code</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49-57">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> principles of <a href="/wiki/Interpretation_(canon_law)" title="Interpretation (canon law)">legal interpretation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> and coercive penalties.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law</a> concerns the Catholic Church's life and organisation and is distinct from civil law. In its own field it gives force to civil law only by specific enactment in matters such as the guardianship of minors.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> Similarly, civil law may give force in its field to canon law, but only by specific enactment, as with regard to canonical marriages.<sup id="cite_ref-Malta_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malta-62">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> Currently, the <a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">1983 Code of Canon Law</a> is in effect for the Latin Church.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> The distinct 1990 <i><a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches</a></i> (<i>CCEO</i>, after the Latin initials) applies to the autonomous <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Latin_and_Eastern_churches">Latin and Eastern churches</span></h3>
<p><span id="Autonomous_particular_churches"></span><span id="Particular_churches_&#39;&#39;sui_iuris&#39;"></span>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a></div>

</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a><br /><a href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg" class="image"><img alt="P christianity.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="14" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="360" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Particular_churches_sui_iuris" title="Template:Particular churches sui iuris"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Particular_churches_sui_iuris" title="Template talk:Particular churches sui iuris"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Particular_churches_sui_iuris&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In the first thousand years of Catholic history, different varieties of Christianity developed in the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> areas of Europe. Though most Eastern-tradition churches are no longer in communion with the Catholic Church after the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054, autonomous <a href="/wiki/Particular_churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Particular churches">particular churches</a> of both traditions currently participate, also known as "churches <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a></i>" (<a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">"of one's own right</i>"). The largest and most well known is the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>, the only Western-tradition church, with more than 1&#160;billion members worldwide. Relatively small in terms of adherents compared to the Latin Church, are the 23 self-governing <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> with a combined membership of 17.3&#160;million as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-Roberson_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roberson-65">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gunton_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton-66">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Latin Church is governed by the pope and diocesan bishops directly appointed by him. The pope exercises a direct <a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">patriarchal</a> role over the Latin Church, which is considered to form the original and still major part of <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>, a heritage of certain beliefs and customs originating in Europe and northwestern Africa, some of which are inherited by many <a href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian denominations">Christian denominations</a> that trace their origins to the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-west_christ_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-west_christ-69">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Eastern Catholic Churches follow the traditions and spirituality of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a> and are churches which have always remained in full communion with the Catholic Church or who have chosen to re-enter full communion in the centuries following the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> and earlier divisions. These churches are communities of Catholic Christians whose forms of worship reflect distinct historical and cultural influences rather than differences in doctrine.
</p><p>A church <i>sui iuris</i> is defined in the <i><a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons for the Eastern Churches</a></i> as a "group of Christian faithful united by a hierarchy" that is recognised by the Pope in his capacity as the <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">supreme authority</a> on matters of doctrine within the church.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> The term is an innovation of the <i>CCEO</i> to denote the relative autonomy of the Eastern Catholic Churches,<sup id="cite_ref-MalankaraCCSIJS_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MalankaraCCSIJS-71">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> who remain in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the Pope, but have governance structures and liturgical traditions separate from that of the Latin Church.<sup id="cite_ref-Gunton_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton-66">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> While the Latin Church's canons do not explicitly use the term, it is tacitly recognised as equivalent.
</p><p>Some Eastern Catholic churches are governed by a patriarch who is elected by the <a href="/wiki/Synod" title="Synod">synod</a> of the bishops of that church,<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO55_150_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO55_150-72">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup> others are headed by a <a href="/wiki/Major_archbishop" title="Major archbishop">major archbishop</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO151_154_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO151_154-73">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> others are under a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop" title="Metropolitan bishop">metropolitan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO155_173_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO155_173-74">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> and others are organised as individual <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO-75">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> Each church has authority over the particulars of its internal organisation, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgical_rites" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic liturgical rites">liturgical rites</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Roman_Calendar" title="General Roman Calendar">liturgical calendar</a> and other aspects of its spirituality, subject only to the authority of the pope.<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO27_7_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO27_7-76">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a> has a specific department, the <a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Oriental_Churches" title="Congregation for the Oriental Churches">Congregation for the Oriental Churches</a>, to maintain relations with them.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup> The pope does not generally appoint bishops or clergy in the Eastern Catholic Churches, deferring to their internal governance structures, but may intervene if he feels it necessary.
</p><p>Of <a href="/wiki/Jesus%27_apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus&#39; apostles">Jesus' apostles</a>, five are associated with <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_see" title="Apostolic see">apostolic sees</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Church">Western Church</a> (except <a href="/wiki/Catholic_titular_sees" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic titular sees">titular sees</a>): 1) <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Rome</a> (together with <a href="/wiki/Saint_Paul" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Paul">Paul</a>), <a href="/wiki/Latin_Patriarchate_of_Jerusalem" title="Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> (together with 2) <a href="/wiki/James,_brother_of_Jesus" title="James, brother of Jesus">James</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Siracusa" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Siracusa">Syracuse</a>, 3) <a href="/wiki/Saint_Paul" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Paul">Paul</a> also founded <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Malta" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Malta">Malta</a>, 4) <a href="/wiki/Saint_Barnabas" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Barnabas">Barnabas</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Milan" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milan">Milan</a>, 5) <a href="/wiki/James_the_Great" title="James the Great">James the Great</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Santiago_de_Compostela" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Santiago de Compostela">Santiago de Compostela</a>. Several others are associated within Eastern Catholic apostolic sees: 6) <a href="/wiki/Mark_the_Evangelist" title="Mark the Evangelist">Mark</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Catholic_Patriarchate_of_Alexandria" title="Coptic Catholic Patriarchate of Alexandria">Alexandra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Peter</a> founded Antioch (<a href="/wiki/Maronite_Catholic_Patriarchate_of_Antioch" title="Maronite Catholic Patriarchate of Antioch">Maronite</a>/<a href="/wiki/Syriac_Catholic_Patriarchs_of_Antioch" title="Syriac Catholic Patriarchs of Antioch">Syriac</a>/<a href="/wiki/Melkite_Catholic_Patriarchate_of_Antioch" title="Melkite Catholic Patriarchate of Antioch">Melkite</a>), 7) <a href="/wiki/Saint_Philip_the_Evangelist" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Philip the Evangelist">Philip</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Catholic_Church" title="Ethiopian Catholic Church">Ethiopia</a>, 8) <a href="/wiki/Saint_Andrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Andrew">Andrew</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Kiev</a>, 9/10) <a href="/wiki/Thaddaeus" class="mw-redirect" title="Thaddaeus">Thaddaeus</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jude_the_Apostle" title="Jude the Apostle">Jude the Apostle</a>; <a href="/wiki/Thaddeus_of_Edessa" title="Thaddeus of Edessa">Thaddeus of Edessa</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Bartholomew_the_Apostle" title="Bartholomew the Apostle">Bartholomew</a> founded <a href="/wiki/Patriarchate_of_Cilicia" title="Patriarchate of Cilicia">Cilicia</a> and together with 10) <a href="/wiki/Thomas_the_Apostle" title="Thomas the Apostle">Thomas</a> also <a href="/wiki/Chaldean_Catholic_Patriarchate_of_Babylon" title="Chaldean Catholic Patriarchate of Babylon">Babylon</a>, the latter who also fonded India (<a href="/wiki/Syro-Malabar_Catholic_Church" title="Syro-Malabar Catholic Church">Syro-Malabar</a>/<a href="/wiki/Syro-Malankara_Catholic_Church" title="Syro-Malankara Catholic Church">Syro-Malankara</a>).
</p>
<h3><span id="Dioceses.2C_parishes.2C_organisations_and_institutes"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dioceses,_parishes,_organisations_and_institutes">Dioceses, parishes, organisations and institutes</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_dioceses_(structured_view)" title="List of Catholic dioceses (structured view)">List of Catholic dioceses (structured view)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parish_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Parish in the Catholic Church">Parish in the Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute" title="Religious institute">Religious institute</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_charities" title="Catholic charities">Catholic charities</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:379px;max-width:379px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:377px;max-width:377px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Catholic_population.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Catholic_population.svg/375px-Catholic_population.svg.png" decoding="async" width="375" height="192" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Catholic_population.svg/563px-Catholic_population.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Catholic_population.svg/750px-Catholic_population.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1314" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">A map of Catholicism by population <i>percentage</i> (for absolute figures, see below)</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:377px;max-width:377px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Catholicism_by_country.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Catholicism_by_country.png/375px-Catholicism_by_country.png" decoding="async" width="375" height="171" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Catholicism_by_country.png/563px-Catholicism_by_country.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Catholicism_by_country.png/750px-Catholicism_by_country.png 2x" data-file-width="1357" data-file-height="617" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Countries by number of Catholics in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-Pew2011_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew2011-78">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> <div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:black; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 100 million</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #555555; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 50 million</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #964B00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 20 million</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FF6700; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 10 million</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FF7518; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 5 million</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFE5B4; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;More than 1 million</div> </div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Individual countries, regions, or major cities are served by <a href="/wiki/Particular_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Particular church">particular churches</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">dioceses</a> in the Latin Church, or <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchies</a> in the Eastern Catholic Churches, each overseen by a bishop. As of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the Catholic Church has 2,795 dioceses.<sup id="cite_ref-sees_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sees-79">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> The bishops in a particular country are members of a national or regional episcopal conference.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Dioceses are divided into <a href="/wiki/Parish" title="Parish">parishes</a>, each with one or more <a href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Priesthood (Catholic Church)">priests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deacon" title="Deacon">deacons</a> or <a href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministry" title="Lay ecclesial ministry">lay ecclesial ministers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OneFaith52_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith52-81">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> Parishes are responsible for the day to day celebration of the sacraments and pastoral care of the laity.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, there are 221,700 parishes worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Latin Church, Catholic men may serve as deacons or priests by receiving sacramental <a href="/wiki/Holy_Orders" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Orders">ordination</a>. Men and women may serve as <a href="/wiki/Extraordinary_minister_of_Holy_Communion" title="Extraordinary minister of Holy Communion">extraordinary ministers of Holy Communion</a>, as readers (lectors); or as <a href="/wiki/Altar_servers" class="mw-redirect" title="Altar servers">altar servers</a>. Historically, boys and men have only been permitted to serve as altar servers; however, since the 1990s, girls and women have also been permitted.<sup id="cite_ref-Apostalicae86_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apostalicae86-84">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;note 6&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ordained Catholics, as well as members of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_laity" title="Catholic laity">laity</a>, may enter into <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_life" title="Consecrated life">consecrated life</a> either on an individual basis, as a <a href="/wiki/Hermit" title="Hermit">hermit</a> or <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_virgin" title="Consecrated virgin">consecrated virgin</a>, or by joining an <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_consecrated_life" title="Institute of consecrated life">institute of consecrated life</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute_(Catholic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious institute (Catholic)">religious institute</a> or a <a href="/wiki/Secular_institute" title="Secular institute">secular institute</a>) in which to take <a href="/wiki/Religious_vows" title="Religious vows">vows</a> confirming their desire to follow the three <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_counsels" title="Evangelical counsels">evangelical counsels</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chastity" title="Chastity">chastity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a> and obedience.<sup id="cite_ref-Canons573-746_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Canons573-746-86">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Examples of institutes of consecrated life are the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_Saint_Benedict" class="mw-redirect" title="Order of Saint Benedict">Benedictines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Carmelites" title="Carmelites">Carmelites</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Franciscan" class="mw-redirect" title="Franciscan">Franciscans</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Missionaries_of_Charity" title="Missionaries of Charity">Missionaries of Charity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Legionaries_of_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Legionaries of Christ">Legionaries of Christ</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_Mercy" title="Sisters of Mercy">Sisters of Mercy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Canons573-746_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Canons573-746-86">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>"Religious institutes" is a modern term encompassing both "<a href="/wiki/Religious_order_(Catholic)" title="Religious order (Catholic)">religious orders</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Religious_congregations" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious congregations">religious congregations</a>" which were once distinguished in <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">canon law</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> The terms "religious order" and "religious institute" tend to be used as synonyms colloquially.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By means of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_charities" title="Catholic charities">Catholic charities</a> and beyond, the Catholic Church is the largest non-government provider of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_education" title="Catholic education">education</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">health care</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Membership">Membership</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations_by_number_of_members" title="List of Christian denominations by number of members">List of Christian denominations by number of members</a></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks hlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding:0.4em 0"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/38px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/50px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="815" data-file-height="1105" /></td></tr><tr><td style="padding-top:0.2em;line-height:1.2em">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Category:Catholic Church by country">a series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;padding-top:0;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0.2em 0 0.4em"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Catholic_World.PNG" class="image"><img alt="Distribution of Catholics around the world" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/The_Catholic_World.PNG/250px-The_Catholic_World.PNG" decoding="async" width="250" height="112" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/The_Catholic_World.PNG/375px-The_Catholic_World.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/The_Catholic_World.PNG/500px-The_Catholic_World.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1427" data-file-height="640" /></a></td></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">

<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Gabon" title="Catholic Church in Gabon">Gabon</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_Gambia" title="Catholic Church in the Gambia">Gambia</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Kenya" title="Catholic Church in Kenya">Kenya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Lesotho" title="Catholic Church in Lesotho">Lesotho</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Liberia" title="Catholic Church in Liberia">Liberia</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Malawi" title="Catholic Church in Malawi">Malawi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Mali" title="Catholic Church in Mali">Mali</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Mauritania" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church in Mauritania">Mauritania</a></li>
