</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Template:Catholic Church by country"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Template talk:Catholic Church by country"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Church_by_country&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Church membership, defined as baptised Catholics, was 1.272 billion at the end of 2014, which is 17.8% of the world population.<sup id="cite_ref-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Catholics represent about half of all Christians.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Geographic distribution of Catholics worldwide continues to shift, with 17% in Africa, 48% in the Americas, 11% Asia, 23% in Europe, and 1% in Oceania.<sup id="cite_ref-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholic ministers include ordained clergy, <a href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministers" class="mw-redirect" title="Lay ecclesial ministers">lay ecclesial ministers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">missionaries</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catechesis" title="Catechesis">catechists</a>. Also as of the end of 2014, there were 465,595 ordained clergy, including 5,237 bishops, 415,792 priests (diocesan and religious), and 44,566 deacons (permanent).<sup id="cite_ref-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016_89-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Non-ordained ministers included 3,157,568 catechists, 367,679 lay missionaries, and 39,951 <a href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministers" class="mw-redirect" title="Lay ecclesial ministers">lay ecclesial ministers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Catholic_Church_Statistics_2015_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_Church_Statistics_2015-91">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics who have committed to religious or consecrated life instead of marriage or single celibacy, as a state of life or relational vocation, include 54,559 male religious, 705,529 women religious. These are not ordained, nor generally considered ministers unless also engaged in one of the lay minister categories above.<sup id="cite_ref-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016_89-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Doctrine">Doctrine</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic theology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Bible" title="Catholic Bible">Catholic Bible</a></div>
<p>Catholic doctrine has developed over the centuries, reflecting direct teachings of early Christians, formal definitions of <a href="/wiki/Heresy_in_Christianity" title="Heresy in Christianity">heretical</a> and orthodox beliefs by <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_councils" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecumenical councils">ecumenical councils</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Papal_bull" title="Papal bull">papal bulls</a>, and theological debate by <a href="/wiki/Scholar" title="Scholar">scholars</a>. The church believes that it is continually guided by the Holy Spirit as it discerns new theological issues and is protected <a href="/wiki/Infallibility_of_the_Church" title="Infallibility of the Church">infallibly</a> from falling into doctrinal error when a firm decision on an issue is reached.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>It teaches that revelation has one common source, <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a>, and two distinct modes of transmission: <a href="/wiki/Books_of_the_Bible" title="Books of the Bible">Sacred Scripture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sacred_Tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Sacred Tradition">Sacred Tradition</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LumenG3_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LumenG3-95">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> and that these are authentically interpreted by the <a href="/wiki/Magisterium" title="Magisterium">Magisterium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_teaching_office_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_teaching_office-96">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> Sacred Scripture consists of the 73 books of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Bible" title="Catholic Bible">Catholic Bible</a>, consisting of 46 <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> and 27 <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> writings. Sacred Tradition consists of those teachings believed by the church to have been handed down since the time of the Apostles.<sup id="cite_ref-Schreck16_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck16-98">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> Sacred Scripture and Sacred Tradition are collectively known as the "deposit of faith" (<i>depositum fidei</i> in Latin). These are in turn interpreted by the Magisterium (from <i>magister</i>, Latin for "teacher"), the church's teaching authority, which is exercised by the pope and the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Bishops" title="College of Bishops">College of Bishops</a> in union with the pope, the bishop of Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-Schreck30_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck30-99">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> Catholic doctrine is authoritatively summarised in the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>, published by the Holy See.<sup id="cite_ref-cat_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cat-100">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature_of_God">Nature of God</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/220px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/330px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/440px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="494" data-file-height="568" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>C. 1210 manuscript version of the traditional <a href="/wiki/Shield_of_the_Trinity" title="Shield of the Trinity">Shield of the Trinity</a> theological diagram</div></div></div><p>The Catholic Church holds that there is <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">one eternal God</a>, who exists as a <i><a href="/wiki/Perichoresis" title="Perichoresis">perichoresis</a></i> ("mutual indwelling") of three <i><a href="/wiki/Hypostasis_(philosophy_and_religion)" title="Hypostasis (philosophy and religion)">hypostases</a></i>, or "persons": <a href="/wiki/God_the_Father#Christianity" title="God the Father">God the Father</a>; <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_in_Christianity" title="Holy Spirit in Christianity">God the Holy Spirit</a>, which together are called the "<a href="/wiki/Holy_Trinity" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Trinity">Holy Trinity</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-232_252_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232_252-102">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics believe that Jesus Christ is the "Second Person" of the Trinity, God the Son. In an event known as the <a href="/wiki/Incarnation_(Christianity)" title="Incarnation (Christianity)">Incarnation</a>, through the power of the Holy Spirit, God became united with human nature through the conception of Christ in the womb of the <a href="/wiki/Blessed_Virgin_Mary" class="mw-redirect" title="Blessed Virgin Mary">Blessed Virgin Mary</a>. Christ, therefore, is understood as being both fully divine and fully human, including possessing a human <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a>. It is taught that Christ's mission on earth included giving people his teachings and providing his example for them to follow as recorded in the four <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">Gospels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McGrath_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGrath-103">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> Jesus is believed to have remained sinless while on earth, and to have allowed himself to be unjustly executed by <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifixion</a>, as sacrifice of himself to reconcile humanity to God; this reconciliation is known as the <a href="/wiki/Paschal_Mystery" class="mw-redirect" title="Paschal Mystery">Paschal Mystery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup> The Greek term "Christ" and the Hebrew "Messiah" both mean "anointed one", referring to the Christian belief that Jesus' death and resurrection are the fulfilment of the Old Testament's <a href="/wiki/Jesus_and_messianic_prophecy" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus and messianic prophecy">messianic prophecies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft71_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft71-105">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Catholic Church teaches dogmatically that "the Holy Spirit proceeds eternally from the Father and the Son, not as from two principles but as from one single principle".<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> It holds that the Father, as the "principle without principle", is the first origin of the Spirit, but also that he, as Father of the only Son, is with the Son the single principle from which the Spirit proceeds.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> This belief is expressed in the <i><a href="/wiki/Filioque" title="Filioque">Filioque</a></i> clause which was added to the Latin version of the <a href="/wiki/Nicene_Creed" title="Nicene Creed">Nicene Creed</a> of 381 but not included in the Greek versions of the creed used in Eastern Christianity.<sup id="cite_ref-245_248_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245_248-108">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature_of_the_church">Nature of the church</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_ecclesiology" title="Catholic ecclesiology">Catholic ecclesiology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pentecost_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Pentecost_01.jpg/220px-Pentecost_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="245" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Pentecost_01.jpg/330px-Pentecost_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Pentecost_01.jpg/440px-Pentecost_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="897" data-file-height="1000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pentecost_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a> depicted in a 14th-century <a href="/wiki/Missal" title="Missal">missal</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that it is the "<a href="/wiki/One_true_church" title="One true church">one true church</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> "the universal sacrament of salvation for the human race",<sup id="cite_ref-GAUDIUM_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GAUDIUM-110">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-111">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> and "the one true religion".<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> According to the <i>Catechism</i>, the Catholic Church is further described in the <a href="/wiki/Nicene_Creed" title="Nicene Creed">Nicene Creed</a> as the "one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church".<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> These are collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">Four Marks of the Church</a>. The church teaches that its founder is Jesus Christ.<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft98_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft98-114">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bokenkotter30_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bokenkotter30-115">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> records several events considered integral to the establishment of the Catholic Church, including Jesus' activities and teaching and his appointment of the <a href="/wiki/Apostles_of_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostles of Christ">apostles</a> as witnesses to his ministry, suffering, and resurrection. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>, after his resurrection, instructed the apostles to continue his work. The coming of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles, in an event known as <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, is seen as the beginning of the public ministry of the Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-Barry48_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry48-116">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> The church teaches that all duly consecrated bishops have a lineal succession from the apostles of Christ, known as <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">apostolic succession</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OneFaith46_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith46-117">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> In particular, the Bishop of Rome (the pope) is considered the successor to the apostle <a href="/wiki/Simon_Peter" class="mw-redirect" title="Simon Peter">Simon Peter</a>, a position from which he derives his <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">supremacy</a> over the church.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholic belief holds that the church "is the continuing presence of Jesus on earth"<sup id="cite_ref-Schreck131_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck131-119">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> and that it alone possesses the full means of <a href="/wiki/Salvation_(Christianity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Salvation (Christianity)">salvation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CCC_816_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_816-120">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> Through the <a href="/wiki/Passion_(Christianity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Passion (Christianity)">passion</a> (suffering) of Christ leading to his <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifixion</a> as described in the Gospels, it is said Christ made himself an oblation to God the Father in order to <a href="/wiki/Atonement_in_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Atonement in Christianity">reconcile</a> humanity to God;<sup id="cite_ref-608_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-608_-121">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">Resurrection of Jesus</a> makes him the firstborn from the dead, the first among many brethren.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> By reconciling with God and following Christ's words and deeds, an individual can enter the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Kingdom of God (Christianity)">Kingdom of God</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-OneFaith26_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith26-123">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The church sees its liturgy and sacraments as perpetuating the graces achieved through Christ's sacrifice to strengthen a person's relationship with Christ and aid in overcoming sin.<sup id="cite_ref-CoCCC_Paschal_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CoCCC_Paschal-124">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_judgement">Final judgement</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment#Catholicism" title="Last Judgment">Last Judgment §&#160;Catholicism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fra_Angelico_024.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fra_Angelico_024.jpg/220px-Fra_Angelico_024.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="244" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fra_Angelico_024.jpg/330px-Fra_Angelico_024.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Fra_Angelico_024.jpg/440px-Fra_Angelico_024.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2536" data-file-height="2811" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Fra_Angelico_024.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Before his <a href="/wiki/Resurrection" title="Resurrection">resurrection</a> from the dead, Jesus Christ grants salvation to souls by the <a href="/wiki/Harrowing_of_Hell" title="Harrowing of Hell">Harrowing of Hell</a>. Fresco by <a href="/wiki/Fra_Angelico" title="Fra Angelico">Fra Angelico</a>, c.&#160;1430s.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that, immediately after death, the <a href="/wiki/Soul_(spirit)" class="mw-redirect" title="Soul (spirit)">soul</a> of each person will receive a <a href="/wiki/Particular_judgment" title="Particular judgment">particular judgement</a> from God, based on their <a href="/wiki/Sin" title="Sin">sins</a> and their relationship to Christ.<sup id="cite_ref-1021_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1021_-125">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Schreck397_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck397-126">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> This teaching also attests to another day when Christ will sit in universal judgement of all mankind. This <a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment" title="Last Judgment">final judgement</a>, according to the church's teaching, will bring an end to human history and mark the beginning of both a new and better heaven and earth ruled by God in righteousness.<sup id="cite_ref-1038_41_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1038_41-127">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Depending on the judgement rendered following death, it is believed that a soul may enter one of three states of afterlife:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Heaven_in_Christianity#Roman_Catholicism" title="Heaven in Christianity">Heaven</a> is a state of unending union with the divine nature of God, not ontologically, but by grace. It is an eternal life, in which the soul contemplates God in ceaseless <a href="/wiki/Beatific_vision" title="Beatific vision">beatitude</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1023_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1023_-128">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Purgatory" title="Purgatory">Purgatory</a> is a temporary condition for the purification of souls who, although destined for Heaven, are not fully detached from sin and thus cannot enter Heaven immediately.<sup id="cite_ref-1030_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1030_-129">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> In Purgatory, the soul suffers, and is purged and perfected. Souls in purgatory may be aided in reaching heaven by the prayers of the faithful on earth and by the <a href="/wiki/Intercession_of_saints" title="Intercession of saints">intercession of saints</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hell_in_Christian_beliefs#Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Hell in Christian beliefs">Final Damnation</a>: Finally, those who persist in living in a state of mortal sin and do not repent before death subject themselves to hell, an everlasting separation from God.<sup id="cite_ref-1033_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1033_-131">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> The church teaches that no one is condemned to hell without having freely decided to reject God.<sup id="cite_ref-1058_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1058_-132">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> No one is <a href="/wiki/Predestination" title="Predestination">predestined</a> to hell and no one can determine with absolute certainty who has been condemned to hell.<sup id="cite_ref-1037_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1037_-133">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> Catholicism teaches that through God's mercy a person can repent at any point before death, be illuminated with the truth of the Catholic faith, and thus obtain salvation.<sup id="cite_ref-Luke23_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Luke23-134">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> Some Catholic theologians have speculated that the souls of unbaptised infants and non-Christians without mortal sin but who die in <a href="/wiki/Original_sin" title="Original sin">original sin</a> are assigned to <a href="/wiki/Limbo" title="Limbo">limbo</a>, although this is not an official <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">dogma</a> of the church.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>While the Catholic Church teaches that it alone possesses the full means of salvation,<sup id="cite_ref-CCC_816_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_816-120">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> it also acknowledges that the Holy Spirit can make use of <a href="/wiki/Ecclesial_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecclesial Community">Christian communities</a> separated from itself to "impel towards Catholic unity"<sup id="cite_ref-ewtn.com_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewtn.com-136">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> and "tend and lead toward the Catholic Church",<sup id="cite_ref-ewtn.com_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewtn.com-136">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> and thus bring people to salvation, because these separated communities contain some elements of proper doctrine, albeit admixed with <a href="/wiki/Heresy" title="Heresy">errors</a>. It teaches that anyone who is saved is saved through the Catholic Church but that people can be saved outside of the ordinary means known as <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_desire" title="Baptism of desire">baptism of desire</a>, and by pre-baptismal martyrdom, known as <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_blood" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of blood">baptism of blood</a>, as well as when conditions of <a href="/wiki/Invincible_ignorance_(Catholic_theology)" title="Invincible ignorance (Catholic theology)">invincible ignorance</a> are present, although invincible ignorance in itself is not a means of salvation.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Saints_and_devotions">Saints and devotions</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">Saint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canonization" title="Canonization">Canonization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">Veneration</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_devotions" title="Catholic devotions">Catholic devotions</a></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saint</a> (also historically known as a hallow) is a person who is recognised as having an exceptional degree of holiness or likeness or closeness to God, while <a href="/wiki/Canonization" title="Canonization">canonization</a> is the act by which a Christian church declares that a person who has died was a saint, upon which declaration the person is included in the "canon", or list, of recognised saints.<sup id="cite_ref-WilsonFischer2005_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WilsonFischer2005-138">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DiehlDonnelly2001_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DiehlDonnelly2001-139">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> The first persons honoured as saints were the <a href="/wiki/Martyr" title="Martyr">martyrs</a>. Pious legends of their deaths were considered affirmations of the truth of their faith in <a href="/wiki/Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Christ">Christ</a>. By the fourth century, however, "<a href="/wiki/Confessor" title="Confessor">confessors</a>"—people who had confessed their faith not by dying but by word and life—began to be <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">venerated publicly</a>.
</p><p>In the Catholic Church, both in Latin and Eastern Catholic churches, the act of canonization is reserved to the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic See">Apostolic See</a> and occurs at the conclusion of a long process requiring extensive proof that the candidate for canonization lived and died in such an exemplary and holy way that he is worthy to be recognised as a saint. The church's official recognition of sanctity implies that the person is now in <a href="/wiki/Heaven" title="Heaven">Heaven</a> and that he may be publicly invoked and mentioned officially in the <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgy</a> of the church, including in the <a href="/wiki/Litany_of_the_Saints" title="Litany of the Saints">Litany of the Saints</a>. <a href="/wiki/Canonization" title="Canonization">Canonization</a> allows universal veneration of the saint in the <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgy</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a>; for permission to venerate merely locally, only <a href="/wiki/Beatification" title="Beatification">beatification</a> is needed.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_devotions" title="Catholic devotions">Devotions</a> are "external practices of piety" which are not part of the official liturgy of the Catholic Church but are part of the popular spiritual practices of Catholics.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> These include various practices regarding the veneration of the saints, especially <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">veneration of the Virgin Mary</a>. Other devotional practices include the <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Stations of the Cross</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sacred_Heart" title="Sacred Heart">Sacred Heart</a> of Jesus, the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Face_of_Jesus" title="Holy Face of Jesus">Holy Face of Jesus</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-etwndevoti_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etwndevoti-142">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> the various <a href="/wiki/Scapular" title="Scapular">scapulars</a>, novenas to various saints,<sup id="cite_ref-popdevos_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popdevos-143">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrimages</a><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> and devotions to the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Eucharist (Catholic Church)">Blessed Sacrament</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-popdevos_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popdevos-143">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> and the veneration of <a href="/wiki/Santo_(art)" title="Santo (art)">saintly images</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Santo_(art)" title="Santo (art)"><i>santos</i></a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> The bishops at the Second Vatican Council reminded Catholics that "devotions should be so drawn up that they harmonise with the liturgical seasons, accord with the sacred liturgy, are in some fashion derived from it, and lead the people to it, since, in fact, the liturgy by its very nature far surpasses any of them."<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Virgin_Mary">Virgin Mary</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariology of the Catholic Church">Mariology of the Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_saints" title="Mariology of the saints">Mariology of the saints</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_popes" title="Mariology of the popes">Mariology of the popes</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary, mother of Jesus</a></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em </tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar" title="Template:Catholic Mariology sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar" title="Template talk:Catholic Mariology sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg/170px-LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="237" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg/255px-LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg/340px-LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1946" data-file-height="2717" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:LaPurisimaInmaculadaConcepciondeRibera.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">Blessed Virgin Mary</a> is highly regarded in the Catholic Church, proclaiming her as <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">Mother of God</a>, <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">free from original sin</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Intercessor" class="mw-redirect" title="Intercessor">intercessor</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Mariology" title="Catholic Mariology">Catholic Mariology</a> deals with the <a href="/wiki/Marian_doctrines_of_the_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Marian doctrines of the Catholic Church">doctrines</a> and teachings concerning the life of the <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary, mother of Jesus</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">veneration of Mary</a> by the faithful. Mary is held in special regard, declared the <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">Mother of God</a> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Θεοτόκος</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>:&#160;</small><i lang="el-Latn" title="Greek-language romanization">Theotokos</i>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>&#160;</small>&#39;God-bearer&#39;), and believed as <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">dogma</a> to have remained a <a href="/wiki/Perpetual_virginity_of_Mary" title="Perpetual virginity of Mary">virgin throughout her life</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-147">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> Further teachings include the doctrines of the <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">Immaculate Conception</a> (her own conception without the stain of original sin) and the <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">Assumption of Mary</a> (that her body was assumed directly into heaven at the end of her life). Both of these doctrines were defined as infallible dogma, by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a> in 1854 and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> in 1950 respectively,<sup id="cite_ref-Barry,_p._106_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry,_p._106-148">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> but only after consulting with the Catholic bishops throughout the world to ascertain that this is a Catholic belief.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Devotions to Mary are part of Catholic piety but are distinct from the worship of God.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> Practices include prayers and <a href="/wiki/Marian_art_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marian art in the Catholic Church">Marian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Marian_music" title="Catholic Marian music">music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Marian_church_buildings" title="Catholic Marian church buildings">architecture</a>. Several liturgical Marian feasts are celebrated throughout the Church Year and she is honoured with many titles such as <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Heaven" title="Queen of Heaven">Queen of Heaven</a>. <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> called her <a href="/wiki/Mother_of_the_Church" title="Mother of the Church">Mother of the Church</a> because, by giving birth to Christ, she is considered to be the spiritual mother to each member of the <a href="/wiki/Body_of_Christ" title="Body of Christ">Body of Christ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Barry,_p._106_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry,_p._106-148">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> Because of her influential role in the life of Jesus, prayers and devotions such as the <a href="/wiki/Hail_Mary" title="Hail Mary">Hail Mary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rosary" title="Rosary">Rosary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Salve_Regina" title="Salve Regina">Salve Regina</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Memorare" title="Memorare">Memorare</a> are common Catholic practices.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</a> to the sites of several <a href="/wiki/Marian_apparitions" class="mw-redirect" title="Marian apparitions">Marian apparitions</a> affirmed by the church, such as <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Lourdes" title="Our Lady of Lourdes">Lourdes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_F%C3%A1tima" title="Our Lady of Fátima">Fátima</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Guadalupe</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> are also popular Catholic devotions.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments">Sacraments</span></h2>
<p><span id="Celebration_of_the_sacraments"></span><span id="Doctrine_of_the_sacraments"></span>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">Sacraments of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg/220px-Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="192" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg/330px-Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg/440px-Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6059" data-file-height="5296" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Seven_Sacraments_Rogier.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Seven_Sacraments_Altarpiece" title="Seven Sacraments Altarpiece">Seven Sacraments Altarpiece</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Rogier_van_der_Weyden" title="Rogier van der Weyden">Rogier van der Weyden</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1448</span></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/220px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/330px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/440px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1543" data-file-height="1102" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mass at the Grotto at <a href="/wiki/Lourdes" title="Lourdes">Lourdes</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chalice" title="Chalice">chalice</a> is displayed to the people immediately after the consecration of the wine.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that it was entrusted with <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">seven sacraments</a> that were instituted by Christ. The number and nature of the sacraments were defined by several <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a>, most recently the Council of Trent.<sup id="cite_ref-1113_14_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1113_14-154">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;note 7&#93;</a></sup> These are <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">Baptism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Confirmation" title="Confirmation">Confirmation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sacrament of Penance (Catholic Church)">Penance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Anointing of the Sick (Catholic Church)">Anointing of the Sick</a> (formerly called Extreme Unction, one of the "<a href="/wiki/Last_Rites" class="mw-redirect" title="Last Rites">Last Rites</a>"), <a href="/wiki/Holy_Orders" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Orders">Holy Orders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_marriage" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic marriage">Holy Matrimony</a>. Sacraments are visible rituals that Catholics see as signs of God's presence and effective channels of God's <a href="/wiki/Grace_(Christianity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grace (Christianity)">grace</a> to all those who receive them with the proper disposition (<i><a href="/wiki/Ex_opere_operato" title="Ex opere operato">ex opere operato</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> categorises the sacraments into three groups, the "sacraments of Christian initiation", "sacraments of healing" and "sacraments at the service of communion and the mission of the faithful". These groups broadly reflect the stages of people's natural and spiritual lives which each sacrament is intended to serve.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The liturgies of the sacraments are central to the church's mission. According to the <i>Catechism</i>:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>In the liturgy of the New Covenant every liturgical action, especially the celebration of the Eucharist and the sacraments, is an encounter between Christ and the Church. The liturgical assembly derives its unity from the "communion of the Holy Spirit" who gathers the children of God into the one Body of Christ. This assembly transcends racial, cultural, social—indeed, all human affinities.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>According to church doctrine, the sacraments of the church require the proper form, matter, and intent to be validly celebrated.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> In addition, the <a href="/wiki/Canon_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Canon Law">Canon Laws</a> for both the Latin Church and the Eastern Catholic Churches govern who may licitly celebrate certain sacraments, as well as strict rules about who may receive the sacraments.<sup id="cite_ref-CoCC291_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CoCC291-160">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> Notably, because the church teaches that Christ is <a href="/wiki/Real_presence#Catholic_and_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Real presence">present</a> in the Eucharist,<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft326_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft326-161">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> those who are conscious of being in a state of mortal sin are forbidden to receive the sacrament until they have received absolution through the <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Reconciliation" class="mw-redirect" title="Sacrament of Reconciliation">sacrament of Reconciliation</a> (Penance).<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft331_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft331-162">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> Catholics are normally obliged to abstain from eating for at least an hour before receiving the sacrament.<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft331_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft331-162">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> Non-Catholics are ordinarily prohibited from receiving the Eucharist as well.<sup id="cite_ref-CoCC291_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CoCC291-160">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics, even if they were in danger of death and unable to approach a Catholic minister, may not ask for the sacraments of the Eucharist, penance or anointing of the sick from someone, such as a Protestant minister, who is not known to be validly ordained in line with Catholic teaching on ordination.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> Likewise, even in grave and pressing need, Catholic ministers may not administer these sacraments to those who do not manifest Catholic faith in the sacrament. In relation to the churches of Eastern Christianity not in communion with the Holy See, the Catholic Church is less restrictive, declaring that "a certain <i>communion in sacris</i>, and so in the Eucharist, given suitable circumstances and the approval of Church authority, is not merely possible but is encouraged."<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_of_initiation">Sacraments of initiation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_initiation" title="Sacraments of initiation">Sacraments of initiation</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Baptism">Baptism</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/220px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="196" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/330px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/440px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2470" data-file-height="2197" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Baptism of <a href="/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo" title="Augustine of Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a> as represented in a sculptural group in <a href="/wiki/Troyes_Cathedral" title="Troyes Cathedral">Troyes Cathedral</a> (1549), <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a></div></div></div>
<p>As viewed by the Catholic Church, Baptism is the first of three sacraments of initiation as a Christian.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> It washes away all sins, both <a href="/wiki/Original_sin" title="Original sin">original sin</a> and personal actual sins.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> It makes a person a member of the church.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> As a gratuitous gift of God that requires no merit on the part of the person who is baptised, it is <a href="/wiki/Infant_baptism" title="Infant baptism">conferred even on children</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> who, though they have no personal sins, need it on account of original sin.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> If a new-born child is in a danger of death, anyone—be it a doctor, a nurse, or a parent—may baptise the child.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> Baptism marks a person permanently and cannot be repeated.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> The Catholic Church recognises as valid baptisms conferred even by people who are not Catholics or Christians, provided that they intend to baptise ("to do what the Church does when she baptises") and that they use the <a href="/wiki/Trinitarian_formula#Use_in_baptism" title="Trinitarian formula">Trinitarian baptismal formula</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Confirmation">Confirmation</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Confirmation_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Confirmation in the Catholic Church">Confirmation in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<p>The Catholic Church sees the sacrament of confirmation as required to complete the grace given in baptism.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> When adults are baptised, confirmation is normally given immediately afterwards,<sup id="cite_ref-cann883_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cann883-176">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> a practice followed even with newly baptised infants in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cceo695_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cceo695-177">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">West</a> confirmation of children is delayed until they are old enough to understand or at the bishop's discretion.<sup id="cite_ref-cann891_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cann891-178">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> In Western Christianity, particularly Catholicism, the sacrament is called <i>confirmation</i>, because it confirms and strengthens the grace of baptism; in the Eastern Churches, it is called <i>chrismation</i>, because the essential rite is the anointing of the person with <a href="/wiki/Chrism" title="Chrism">chrism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Chrism_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chrism-179">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> a mixture of <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a> and some perfumed substance, usually <a href="/wiki/Oleoresin" title="Oleoresin">balsam</a>, blessed by a bishop.<sup id="cite_ref-Chrism_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chrism-179">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> Those who receive confirmation must be in a state of grace, which for those who have reached the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_reason_(canon_law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Age of reason (canon law)">age of reason</a> means that they should first be cleansed spiritually by the sacrament of Penance; they should also have the intention of receiving the sacrament, and be prepared to show in their lives that they are Christians.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Eucharist">Eucharist</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BentoXVI-51-11052007_(frag).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg/220px-BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="291" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg/330px-BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="416" data-file-height="550" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BentoXVI-51-11052007_(frag).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> celebrates the Eucharist at the <a href="/wiki/Canonisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Canonisation">canonisation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Frei_Galv%C3%A3o" title="Frei Galvão">Frei Galvão</a> in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, Brazil on 11 May 2007</div></div></div>
<p>For Catholics, the Eucharist is the sacrament which completes Christian initiation. It is described as "the source and summit of the Christian life".<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> The ceremony in which a Catholic first receives the Eucharist is known as <a href="/wiki/First_Communion" title="First Communion">First Communion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Eucharistic celebration, also called the <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">Mass</a> or <a href="/wiki/Divine_liturgy" class="mw-redirect" title="Divine liturgy">Divine liturgy</a>, includes prayers and scriptural readings, as well as an offering of bread and wine, which are brought to the <a href="/wiki/Altar" title="Altar">altar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecrated</a> by the priest to become the body and the blood of Jesus Christ, a change called <a href="/wiki/Transubstantiation" title="Transubstantiation">transubstantiation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;note 8&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Words_of_consecration" class="mw-redirect" title="Words of consecration">words of consecration</a> reflect the words spoken by Jesus during the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, where Christ offered his body and blood to his Apostles the night before his crucifixion. The sacrament re-presents (makes present) the sacrifice of Jesus on the cross,<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> and perpetuates it. Christ's death and resurrection gives grace through the sacrament that unites the faithful with Christ and one another, remits venial sin, and aids against committing moral sin (though mortal sin itself is forgiven through the sacrament of penance).<sup id="cite_ref-ccc1392_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccc1392-187">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/170px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="254" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/255px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/340px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="3872" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Catholic believer prays in a church in <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_of_healing">Sacraments of healing</span></h3>
<p>The two sacraments of healing are the <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sacrament of Penance (Catholic Church)">Sacrament of Penance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Anointing of the Sick (Catholic Church)">Anointing of the Sick</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Penance">Penance</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance" title="Sacrament of Penance">Sacrament of Penance</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance" title="Sacrament of Penance">Sacrament of Penance</a> (also called Reconciliation, Forgiveness, Confession, and Conversion<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup>) exists for the conversion of those who, after baptism, separate themselves from Christ by sin.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> Essential to this sacrament are acts both by the sinner (examination of conscience, contrition with a determination not to sin again, confession to a priest, and performance of some act to repair the damage caused by sin) and by the priest (determination of the act of reparation to be performed and <a href="/wiki/Absolution" title="Absolution">absolution</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> Serious sins (<a href="/wiki/Mortal_sin" title="Mortal sin">mortal sins</a>) should be confessed at least once a year and always before receiving Holy Communion, while confession of <a href="/wiki/Venial_sin" title="Venial sin">venial sins</a> also is recommended.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> The priest is bound under the severest penalties to maintain the "<a href="/wiki/Seal_of_confession" class="mw-redirect" title="Seal of confession">seal of confession</a>", absolute secrecy about any sins revealed to him in confession.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Anointing_of_the_sick">Anointing of the sick</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Anointing of the Sick in the Catholic Church">Anointing of the Sick in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:243px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ae/Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg" decoding="async" width="241" height="254" class="thumbimage" data-file-width="241" data-file-height="254" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sacraments_Altarpiece" title="Seven Sacraments Altarpiece">Seven Sacraments Altarpiece</a> <a href="/wiki/Triptych" title="Triptych">triptych</a> painting of Extreme Unction (Anointing of the Sick) with oil being administered by a priest during last rites. <a href="/wiki/Rogier_van_der_Weyden" title="Rogier van der Weyden">Rogier van der Weyden</a>, c.&#160;1445.</div></div></div>
<p>While chrism is used only for the three sacraments that cannot be repeated, a different oil is used by a priest or bishop to bless a Catholic who, because of illness or old age, has begun to be in danger of death.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> This sacrament, known as Anointing of the Sick, is believed to give comfort, peace, courage and, if the sick person is unable to make a confession, even forgiveness of sins.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The sacrament is also referred to as <i>Unction</i>, and in the past as <i>Extreme Unction</i>, and it is one of the three sacraments that constitute the <a href="/wiki/Last_rites" title="Last rites">last rites</a>, together with Penance and <a href="/wiki/Viaticum" title="Viaticum">Viaticum</a> (Eucharist).<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_at_the_service_of_communion">Sacraments at the service of communion</span></h3>
<p>According to the Catechism, there are two sacraments of <a href="/wiki/Koinonia" title="Koinonia">communion</a> directed towards the salvation of others: priesthood and marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-1534_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1534_-196">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> Within the general vocation to be a Christian, these two sacraments "consecrate to specific mission or <a href="/wiki/Vocation" title="Vocation">vocation</a> among the people of God. Men receive the holy orders to feed the Church by the word and <a href="/wiki/Grace_(Christianity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Grace (Christianity)">grace</a>. Spouses marry so that their love may be fortified to fulfill duties of their state".<sup id="cite_ref-1535_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1535_-197">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_Orders">Holy Orders</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Holy_orders_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Holy orders in the Catholic Church">Holy orders in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/220px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/330px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/440px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2084" data-file-height="1389" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Priests lay their hands on the ordinands during the rite of ordination.</div></div></div>
<p>The sacrament of <a href="/wiki/Holy_Orders_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Orders (Catholic Church)">Holy Orders</a> consecrates and deputes some Christians to serve the whole body as members of three degrees or orders: episcopate (bishops), presbyterate (priests) and diaconate (deacons).<sup id="cite_ref-cann10081009_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cann10081009-198">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-1536_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1536_-199">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> The church has defined rules on who may be ordained into the <a href="/wiki/Clergy" title="Clergy">clergy</a>. In the Latin Church, the priesthood is generally restricted to celibate men, and the episcopate is always restricted to celibate men.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> Men who are already married may be ordained in certain Eastern Catholic churches in most countries,<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> and the personal ordinariates and may become deacons even in the Western Church<sup id="cite_ref-CCL1031_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCL1031-202">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CCL1037_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCL1037-203">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> (see <a href="/wiki/Clerical_marriage" title="Clerical marriage">Clerical marriage</a>). But after becoming a Catholic priest, a man may not marry (see <a href="/wiki/Clerical_celibacy" title="Clerical celibacy">Clerical celibacy</a>) unless he is formally laicised.
</p><p>All clergy, whether deacons, priests or bishops, may preach, teach, baptise, witness marriages and conduct funeral liturgies.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> Only bishops and priests can administer the sacraments of the Eucharist, Reconciliation (Penance) and Anointing of the Sick.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> Only bishops can administer the sacrament of Holy Orders, which <a href="/wiki/Ordination" title="Ordination">ordains</a> someone into the clergy.<sup id="cite_ref-OneFaith114_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith114-207">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Matrimony">Matrimony</span></h4>
<p><span id="Sacrament_of_marriage"></span>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marriage in the Catholic Church">Marriage in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">Catholic teachings on sexual morality</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/220px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/330px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/440px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wedding mass in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that marriage is a social and spiritual bond between a man and a woman, ordered towards the good of the spouses and procreation of children; according to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">Catholic teachings on sexual morality</a>, it is the only appropriate context for sexual activity. A Catholic marriage, or any marriage between baptised individuals of any Christian denomination, is viewed as a sacrament. A sacramental marriage, once consummated, cannot be dissolved except by death.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;note 9&#93;</a></sup> The church recognises certain <a href="/wiki/Marriage_(Catholic_Church)#Conditions_for_a_valid_marriage_of_Catholics" class="mw-redirect" title="Marriage (Catholic Church)">conditions</a>, such as freedom of consent, as required for any marriage to be valid; In addition, the church sets specific rules and norms, known as <a href="/wiki/Marriage_(Catholic_Church)#Canonical_form" class="mw-redirect" title="Marriage (Catholic Church)">canonical form</a>, that Catholics must follow.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The church does not recognise divorce as ending a valid marriage and allows state-recognised divorce only as a means of protecting the property and well being of the spouses and any children. However, consideration of particular cases by the competent ecclesiastical tribunal can lead to declaration of the invalidity of a marriage, a declaration usually referred to as an <a href="/wiki/Annulment_(Catholic_Church)" class="mw-redirect" title="Annulment (Catholic Church)">annulment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-annulment_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-annulment-213">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> Remarriage following a divorce is not permitted unless the prior marriage was declared invalid.<sup id="cite_ref-annulment_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-annulment-213">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Liturgy">Liturgy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgy" title="Catholic liturgy">Catholic liturgy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thebible33.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/220px-Thebible33.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/330px-Thebible33.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/440px-Thebible33.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Thebible33.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Catholic religious objects – <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Holy Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crucifix" title="Crucifix">crucifix</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rosary" title="Rosary">rosary</a></div></div></div>
<p>Among the 24 autonomous (<i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a></i>) churches, numerous liturgical and other traditions exist, called rites, which reflect historical and cultural diversity rather than differences in belief.<sup id="cite_ref-1200_09_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1200_09-214">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> In the definition of the <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches</a>, "a rite is the liturgical, theological, spiritual, and disciplinary patrimony, culture and circumstances of history of a distinct people, by which its own manner of living the faith is manifested in each Church <i>sui iuris</i>".<sup id="cite_ref-CCEO28_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO28-215">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The liturgy of the sacrament of the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a>, called the <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">Mass</a> in the West and <a href="/wiki/Divine_Liturgy" title="Divine Liturgy">Divine Liturgy</a> or other names in the East, is the principal liturgy of the Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> This is because it is considered the propitiatory sacrifice of Christ himself.<sup id="cite_ref-scborromeo.org_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scborromeo.org-217">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> Its most widely used form is that of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> as promulgated by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Paul VI</a> in 1969 and revised by <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> in 2002. In certain circumstances the <a href="/wiki/1962_Roman_Missal" class="mw-redirect" title="1962 Roman Missal">1962 form</a> of the Roman Rite remains authorised in the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> have their own rites. The liturgies of the Eucharist and the other sacraments vary from rite to rite, reflecting different theological emphases.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_rites">Western rites</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">Latin liturgical rites</a></div>
