D. <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)#Concluding_rite" title="Mass (liturgy)">Concluding rites</a></th></tr><tr><td class="hlist" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<i>"<a href="/wiki/Ite,_missa_est" title="Ite, missa est">Ite, missa est</a>!"</i></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Roman_Rite_of_Mass" title="Template:Roman Rite of Mass"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Roman_Rite_of_Mass" title="Template talk:Roman Rite of Mass"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Roman_Rite_of_Mass&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> is the most common <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgical_rites" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic liturgical rites">rite of worship</a> used by the Catholic Church. Its use is found worldwide, originating in Rome and spreading throughout Europe, influencing and eventually supplanting local rites.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> The present ordinary form of Mass in the Roman Rite, found in the post-1969 editions of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Missal" title="Roman Missal">Roman Missal</a>, is usually celebrated in the local <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> language, using an officially approved translation from the original text in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>. An outline of its major liturgical elements can be found in the side bar.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Missa_tridentina_002.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Missa_tridentina_002.jpg/220px-Missa_tridentina_002.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="295" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Missa_tridentina_002.jpg/330px-Missa_tridentina_002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Missa_tridentina_002.jpg/440px-Missa_tridentina_002.jpg 2x" data-file-width="540" data-file-height="723" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Missa_tridentina_002.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Elevation of the <a href="/wiki/Chalice" title="Chalice">chalice</a> before an <a href="/wiki/Altar" title="Altar">altar</a> after the consecration during a <a href="/wiki/Solemn_Mass" title="Solemn Mass">Solemn Mass</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tridentine_Mass" title="Tridentine Mass">Tridentine Mass</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2007, Pope Benedict XVI affirmed the licitness of continued use of the <a href="/wiki/1962_Roman_Missal" class="mw-redirect" title="1962 Roman Missal">1962 Roman Missal</a> as an "extraordinary form" (<i>forma extraordinaria</i>) of the Roman Rite, speaking of it also as an <i>usus antiquior</i> ("older use"), and issuing new more permissive norms for its employment.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> An instruction issued four years later spoke of the two forms or usages of the Roman Rite approved by the pope as the ordinary form and the extraordinary form ("the <i>forma ordinaria</i>" and "the <i>forma extraordinaria</i>").<sup id="cite_ref-Universae_Ecclesiae_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Universae_Ecclesiae-220">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1962 edition of the Roman Missal, published a few months before the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> opened, was the last that presented the Mass as standardised in 1570 by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_V" title="Pope Pius V">Pope Pius V</a> at the request of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> and that is therefore known as the Tridentine Mass.<sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft326_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft326-161">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> Pope Pius V's Roman Missal was subjected to minor revisions by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VIII" title="Pope Clement VIII">Pope Clement VIII</a> in 1604, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_VIII" title="Pope Urban VIII">Pope Urban VIII</a> in 1634, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_X" title="Pope Pius X">Pope Pius X</a> in 1911, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> in 1955, and <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a> in 1962. Each successive edition was the ordinary form of the Roman Rite Mass until superseded by a later edition. When the 1962 edition was superseded by that of Paul VI, promulgated in 1969, its continued use at first required permission from bishops;<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> but <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>'s 2007 <a href="/wiki/Motu_proprio" title="Motu proprio">motu proprio</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Summorum_Pontificum" title="Summorum Pontificum">Summorum Pontificum</a></i> allowed free use of it for Mass celebrated without a congregation and authorised parish priests to permit, under certain conditions, its use even at public Masses. Except for the scriptural readings, which Pope Benedict allowed to be proclaimed in the vernacular language, it is celebrated exclusively in <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_Latin" class="mw-redirect" title="Liturgical Latin">liturgical Latin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2014, clergy in the small <a href="/wiki/Personal_ordinariate" title="Personal ordinariate">personal ordinariates</a> set up for groups of former Anglicans under the terms of the 2009 document <i><a href="/wiki/Anglicanorum_Coetibus" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglicanorum Coetibus">Anglicanorum Coetibus</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Anglicanorum_Coetibus_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anglicanorum_Coetibus-223">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> are permitted to use a variation of the Roman Rite called "Divine Worship" or, less formally, "Ordinariate Use",<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> which incorporates elements of the <a href="/wiki/Anglican_liturgy" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglican liturgy">Anglican liturgy</a> and traditions, <sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;note 10&#93;</a></sup> an accommodation protested by Anglican leaders.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Milan" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milan">Archdiocese of Milan</a>, with around five million Catholics the largest in Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> Mass is celebrated according to the <a href="/wiki/Ambrosian_Rite" title="Ambrosian Rite">Ambrosian Rite</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">Latin Church rites</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Mozarabic_Rite" title="Mozarabic Rite">Mozarabic</a><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> and those of some religious institutes.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> These liturgical rites have an antiquity of at least 200 years before 1570, the date of Pope Pius V's <i><a href="/wiki/Quo_primum" title="Quo primum">Quo primum</a></i>, and were thus allowed to continue.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_rites">Eastern rites</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites#Eastern_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites §&#160;Eastern rites</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/220px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/330px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/440px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4834" data-file-height="3684" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/East_Syrian_Rite" class="mw-redirect" title="East Syrian Rite">East Syrian Rite</a> <a href="/wiki/Wedding_crowning" class="mw-redirect" title="Wedding crowning">wedding crowning</a> celebrated by a bishop of the <a href="/wiki/Syro-Malabar_Catholic_Church" title="Syro-Malabar Catholic Church">Syro-Malabar Catholic Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, one of the 23 <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> and the Catholic Church.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a> share common patrimony and liturgical rites as their counterparts, including <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> churches who are no longer in communion with the Holy See. These include churches that historically developed in Russia, Caucasus, the Balkans, North Eastern Africa, India and the Middle East. The Eastern Catholic Churches are groups of faithful who have either never been out of communion with the Holy See or who have restored communion with it at the cost of breaking communion with their associates of the same tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The rites used by the Eastern Catholic Churches include the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Rite" title="Byzantine Rite">Byzantine Rite</a>, in its Antiochian, Greek and Slavonic varieties; the <a href="/wiki/Alexandrian_Rite" title="Alexandrian Rite">Alexandrian Rite</a>; the <a href="/wiki/West_Syrian_Rite" class="mw-redirect" title="West Syrian Rite">Syriac Rite</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Rite" title="Armenian Rite">Armenian Rite</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Maronite_Rite" class="mw-redirect" title="Maronite Rite">Maronite Rite</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chaldean_Rite" class="mw-redirect" title="Chaldean Rite">Chaldean Rite</a>. Eastern Catholic Churches have the autonomy to set the particulars of their liturgical forms and worship, within certain limits to protect the "accurate observance" of their liturgical tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> In the past some of the rites used by the Eastern Catholic Churches were subject to a degree of <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_Latinisation" title="Liturgical Latinisation">liturgical Latinisation</a>. However, in recent years Eastern Catholic Churches have returned to traditional Eastern practices in accord with the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Vatican II</a> decree <i><a href="/wiki/Orientalium_Ecclesiarum" title="Orientalium Ecclesiarum">Orientalium Ecclesiarum</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> Each church has its own <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Liturgical calendar">liturgical calendar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_and_cultural_issues"><span id="Social_and_cultural_issues"></span><span id="Social,_environmental_and_cultural_issues"></span>Social and cultural issues</span></h2>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks plainlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding-top:0.4em;line-height:1.2em">Part of a <a href="/wiki/Category:Catholic_social_teaching" title="Category:Catholic social teaching">series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;padding-top:0;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0.2em 0 0.4em"><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg" class="image"><img alt="Emblem of the Holy See" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/75px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" decoding="async" width="75" height="102" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/113px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/150px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="815" data-file-height="1105" /></a><div style="padding-top:0.2em;line-height:1.2em"><span style="font-size:90%;"><a href="/wiki/Emblem" title="Emblem">Emblem</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a></span></div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.1em;background-color:gold">

<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="32" height="24" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/48px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/64px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_social_teaching" title="Template:Catholic social teaching"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_social_teaching" title="Template talk:Catholic social teaching"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_social_teaching&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Catholic_social_teaching">Catholic social teaching</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a>, reflecting the concern Jesus showed for the impoverished, places a heavy emphasis on the <a href="/wiki/Corporal_works_of_mercy" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporal works of mercy">corporal works of mercy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_works_of_mercy" class="mw-redirect" title="Spiritual works of mercy">spiritual works of mercy</a>, namely the support and concern for the sick, the poor and the afflicted.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Compendium_of_the_CCC,_388_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Compendium_of_the_CCC,_388-235">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> Church teaching calls for a preferential <a href="/wiki/Option_for_the_poor" title="Option for the poor">option for the poor</a> while canon law prescribes that "The Christian faithful are also obliged to promote <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a> and, mindful of the precept of the Lord, to assist the poor."<sup id="cite_ref-Cann22_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cann22-236">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> Its foundations are widely considered to have been laid by Pope Leo XIII's 1891 encyclical letter <a href="/wiki/Rerum_novarum" title="Rerum novarum">Rerum novarum</a> which upholds the rights and dignity of labor and the right of workers to form unions.
</p><p>Catholic teaching regarding sexuality calls for a practice of <a href="/wiki/Chastity" title="Chastity">chastity</a>, with a focus on maintaining the spiritual and bodily integrity of the human person. Marriage is considered the only appropriate context for sexual activity.<sup id="cite_ref-2337_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2337_-237">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> Church teachings about sexuality have become an issue of increasing controversy, especially after the close of the Second Vatican Council, due to changing cultural attitudes in the Western world described as the <a href="/wiki/Sexual_revolution" title="Sexual revolution">sexual revolution</a>.
</p><p>The church has also addressed stewardship of the natural environment, and its relationship to other social and theological teachings. In the document <i><a href="/wiki/Laudato_si%27" title="Laudato si&#39;">Laudato si'</a></i>, dated 24 May 2015, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> critiques <a href="/wiki/Consumerism" title="Consumerism">consumerism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Overdevelopment" title="Overdevelopment">irresponsible development</a>, and laments <a href="/wiki/Environmental_degradation" title="Environmental degradation">environmental degradation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-238">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> The pope expressed concern that the warming of the planet is a symptom of a greater problem: the developed world's indifference to the destruction of the planet as humans pursue short-term economic gains.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_services">Social services</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">Catholic Church and health care</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_school" title="Catholic school">Catholic education</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MotherTeresa_090.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/MotherTeresa_090.jpg/170px-MotherTeresa_090.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/MotherTeresa_090.jpg/255px-MotherTeresa_090.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/MotherTeresa_090.jpg/340px-MotherTeresa_090.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="768" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MotherTeresa_090.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Saint <a href="/wiki/Mother_Teresa" title="Mother Teresa">Teresa</a> of Calcutta advocated for the sick, the poor and the needy by practising the acts of <a href="/wiki/Corporal_works_of_mercy" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporal works of mercy">corporal works of mercy</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church is the largest non-government provider of education and medical services in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> In 2010, the Catholic Church's Pontifical Council for Pastoral Assistance to Health Care Workers said that the church manages 26% of health care facilities in the world, including hospitals, clinics, orphanages, pharmacies and centres for those with leprosy.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The church has always been involved in education, since the founding of the first universities of Europe. It runs and sponsors thousands of primary and secondary schools, colleges and universities throughout the world<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> and operates the world's largest non-governmental school system.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Religious institutes for women have played a particularly prominent role in the provision of health and education services,<sup id="cite_ref-nunsworldwide_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nunsworldwide-244">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> as with orders such as the <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_Mercy" title="Sisters of Mercy">Sisters of Mercy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Sisters_of_the_Poor" title="Little Sisters of the Poor">Little Sisters of the Poor</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Missionaries_of_Charity" title="Missionaries of Charity">Missionaries of Charity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_St._Joseph_of_the_Sacred_Heart" class="mw-redirect" title="Sisters of St. Joseph of the Sacred Heart">Sisters of St. Joseph of the Sacred Heart</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_the_Blessed_Sacrament" title="Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament">Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Daughters_of_Charity_of_Saint_Vincent_de_Paul" title="Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul">Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> The Catholic nun <a href="/wiki/Mother_Teresa" title="Mother Teresa">Mother Teresa</a> of <a href="/wiki/Calcutta,_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Calcutta, India">Calcutta, India</a>, founder of the Missionaries of Charity, was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> in 1979 for her humanitarian work among India's poor.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> Bishop <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Filipe_Ximenes_Belo" title="Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo">Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo</a> won the same award in 1996 for "work towards a just and peaceful solution to the conflict in East Timor".<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The church is also actively engaged in international aid and development through organisations such as <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Relief_Services" title="Catholic Relief Services">Catholic Relief Services</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caritas_International" class="mw-redirect" title="Caritas International">Caritas International</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aid_to_the_Church_in_Need" title="Aid to the Church in Need">Aid to the Church in Need</a>, refugee advocacy groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Jesuit_Refugee_Service" title="Jesuit Refugee Service">Jesuit Refugee Service</a> and community aid groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Vincent_de_Paul_Society" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Vincent de Paul Society">Saint Vincent de Paul Society</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_morality">Sexual morality</span></h3>
<p><span id="chastity_and_marriage"></span>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology_of_sexuality" title="Catholic theology of sexuality">Catholic theology of sexuality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology_of_the_body" title="Catholic theology of the body">Catholic theology of the body</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marriage in the Catholic Church">Marriage in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg/200px-Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="244" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg/300px-Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg/400px-Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg 2x" data-file-width="819" data-file-height="1001" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hans_Memling_-_Allegory_with_a_Virgin_-_WGA14896.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Allegory" title="Allegory">Allegory</a> of chastity by <a href="/wiki/Hans_Memling" title="Hans Memling">Hans Memling</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church calls all members to practise <a href="/wiki/Chastity" title="Chastity">chastity</a> according to their state in life. Chastity includes <a href="/wiki/Temperance_(virtue)" title="Temperance (virtue)">temperance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Discipline" title="Discipline">self-mastery</a>, personal and cultural growth, and <a href="/wiki/Divine_grace" title="Divine grace">divine grace</a>. It requires refraining from <a href="/wiki/Lust" title="Lust">lust</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masturbation" title="Masturbation">masturbation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fornication" title="Fornication">fornication</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pornography" title="Pornography">pornography</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prostitution" title="Prostitution">prostitution</a> and, especially, <a href="/wiki/Rape" title="Rape">rape</a>. Chastity for those who are not married requires living in <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abstinence" title="Sexual abstinence">continence</a>, abstaining from sexual activity; those who are married are called to conjugal chastity.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the church's teaching, sexual activity is reserved to married couples, whether in a <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marriage in the Catholic Church">sacramental marriage</a> among Christians, or in a <a href="/wiki/Natural_marriage" title="Natural marriage">natural marriage</a> where one or both spouses are unbaptised. Even in romantic relationships, particularly <a href="/wiki/Engagement_to_marriage" class="mw-redirect" title="Engagement to marriage">engagement to marriage</a>, partners are called to practise continence, in order to test mutual respect and fidelity.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> Chastity in marriage requires in particular conjugal fidelity and protecting the fecundity of marriage. The couple must foster trust and honesty as well as spiritual and physical intimacy. Sexual activity must always be open to the possibility of life;<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> the church calls this the procreative significance. It must likewise always bring a couple together in love; the church calls this the unitive significance.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Contraception" class="mw-redirect" title="Contraception">Contraception</a> and certain other <a href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality#The_Catholic_teaching_on_specific_subjects" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">sexual practices</a> are not permitted, although <a href="/wiki/Natural_family_planning" title="Natural family planning">natural family planning</a> methods are permitted to provide healthy spacing between births, or to postpone children for a just reason.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> said in 2015 that he is worried that the church has grown "obsessed" with issues such as <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a> and contraception and has criticised the Catholic Church for placing <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">dogma</a> before <a href="/wiki/Charity_(virtue)" title="Charity (virtue)">love</a>, and for prioritising moral doctrines over helping the poor and marginalised.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Divorce_and_declarations_of_nullity">Divorce and declarations of nullity</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_nullity" title="Declaration of nullity">Declaration of nullity</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Divorce_law_by_country" title="Divorce law by country">Divorce law by country</a></div>
<p>Canon law makes no provision for divorce between baptised individuals, as a valid, consummated sacramental marriage is considered to be a lifelong bond.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> However, a declaration of nullity may be granted when proof is produced that essential conditions for contracting a valid marriage were absent from the beginning—in other words, that the marriage was not valid due to some impediment. A declaration of nullity, commonly called an annulment, is a judgement on the part of an <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_tribunal" class="mw-redirect" title="Ecclesiastical tribunal">ecclesiastical tribunal</a> determining that a marriage was invalidly attempted.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> In addition, marriages among unbaptised individuals may be dissolved with papal permission under certain situations, such as a desire to marry a Catholic, under <a href="/wiki/Pauline_privilege" title="Pauline privilege">Pauline</a> or <a href="/wiki/Petrine_privilege" title="Petrine privilege">Petrine privilege</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gantley_209-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gantley-209">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Doors_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Doors-210">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> An attempt at remarriage following divorce without a declaration of nullity places "the remarried spouse ... in a situation of public and permanent adultery". An innocent spouse who lives in continence following divorce, or couples who live in continence following a civil divorce for a grave cause, do not sin.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Worldwide, diocesan tribunals completed over 49000 cases for nullity of marriage in 2006. Over the past 30 years about 55 to 70% of annulments have occurred in the United States. The growth in annulments has been substantial; in the United States, 27,000 marriages were annulled in 2006, compared to 338 in 1968. However, approximately 200,000 married Catholics in the United States divorce each year; 10&#160;million total as of 2006<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-Soule_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soule-259">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;note 11&#93;</a></sup> Divorce is increasing in some predominantly Catholic countries in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> In some predominantly Catholic countries, it is only in recent years that divorce was introduced (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> (1970), <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> (1975), <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> (1977), <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (1981), <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> (1996), <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> (2004) and <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a> (2011), while the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> have no procedure for divorce. (The <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> does, however, allow divorce for Muslims.)
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Contraception"><span id="Sex_and_contraception"></span><span id="contraception"></span>Contraception</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Christian_views_on_contraception#Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Christian views on contraception">Christian views on contraception §&#160;Catholic Church</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_HIV/AIDS" title="Catholic Church and HIV/AIDS">Catholic Church and HIV/AIDS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religious_response_to_assisted_reproductive_technology#Catholicism" title="Religious response to assisted reproductive technology">Religious response to assisted reproductive technology §&#160;Catholicism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Paulaudenece1977.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Paulaudenece1977.jpg/180px-Paulaudenece1977.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="257" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Paulaudenece1977.jpg/270px-Paulaudenece1977.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Paulaudenece1977.jpg/360px-Paulaudenece1977.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1241" data-file-height="1773" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Paulaudenece1977.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> issued <i><a href="/wiki/Humanae_vitae" title="Humanae vitae">Humanae vitae</a></i> on 25 July 1968.</div></div></div>
<p>The church teaches that <a href="/wiki/Sexual_intercourse" title="Sexual intercourse">sexual intercourse</a> should only take place between a man and woman who are married to each other, and should be without the use of <a href="/wiki/Birth_control" title="Birth control">birth control</a> or <a href="/wiki/Contraception" class="mw-redirect" title="Contraception">contraception</a>. In his encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Humanae_vitae" title="Humanae vitae">Humanae vitae</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-humanae_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-humanae-263">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> (1968), <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> firmly rejected all contraception, thus contradicting dissenters in the church that saw the <a href="/wiki/Birth_control_pill" class="mw-redirect" title="Birth control pill">birth control pill</a> as an ethically justifiable method of contraception, though he permitted the regulation of births by means of natural family planning. This teaching was continued especially by <a href="/wiki/John_Paul_II" class="mw-redirect" title="John Paul II">John Paul II</a> in his encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Evangelium_Vitae" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelium Vitae">Evangelium Vitae</a></i>, where he clarified the church's position on contraception, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_abortion" title="Catholic Church and abortion">abortion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia" title="Euthanasia">euthanasia</a> by condemning them as part of a "culture of death" and calling instead for a "<a href="/wiki/Culture_of_life" title="Culture of life">culture of life</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Bokenkotter493_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bokenkotter493-264">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Western Catholics have voiced significant disagreement with the church's teaching on contraception.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catholics_for_Choice" title="Catholics for Choice">Catholics for Choice</a>, a political lobbyist group which is not associated with the Catholic Church, stated in 1998 that 96% of U.S. Catholic women had used contraceptives at some point in their lives and that 72% of Catholics believed that one could be a good Catholic without obeying the church's teaching on birth control.<sup id="cite_ref-cath_choice_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cath_choice-266">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> Use of natural family planning methods among United States Catholics purportedly is low, although the number cannot be known with certainty.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;note 12&#93;</a></sup> As Catholic health providers are among the largest providers of services to patients with <a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS" title="HIV/AIDS">HIV/AIDS</a> worldwide, there is significant controversy within and outside the church regarding the use of condoms as a means of limiting new infections, as <a href="/wiki/Condom" title="Condom">condom</a> use ordinarily constitutes prohibited contraceptive use.<sup id="cite_ref-CNS.AIDS_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNS.AIDS-270">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Similarly, the Catholic Church opposes <a href="/wiki/In_vitro_fertilization" class="mw-redirect" title="In vitro fertilization">in vitro fertilisation</a> (IVF), saying that the artificial process replaces the love between a husband and wife.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> In addition, it opposes IVF because it might cause disposal of embryos; Catholics believe an embryo is an individual with a <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a> who must be treated as such.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> For this reason, the church also opposes <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_abortion" title="Catholic Church and abortion">abortion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Homosexuality">Homosexuality</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality_and_the_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Homosexuality and the Catholic Church">Homosexuality and the Catholic Church</a></div>
<p>The Catholic Church also teaches that "homosexual acts" are "contrary to the natural law", "acts of grave depravity" and "under no circumstances can they be approved", but that persons experiencing homosexual tendencies must be accorded respect and dignity.<sup id="cite_ref-2357_2359_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2357_2359-274">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>,
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The number of men and women who have deep-seated homosexual tendencies is not negligible. This inclination, which is objectively disordered, constitutes for most of them a trial. They must be accepted with respect, compassion, and sensitivity. Every sign of unjust discrimination in their regard should be avoided. ...
</p><p>Homosexual persons are called to chastity. By the virtues of self-mastery that teach them inner freedom, at times by the support of disinterested friendship, by prayer and sacramental grace, they can and should gradually and resolutely approach Christian perfection.<sup id="cite_ref-2358_59_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2358_59-275">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
</blockquote>
<p>This part of the <i>Catechism</i> was quoted by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a> in a 2013 press interview in which he remarked, when asked about an individual:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>I think that when you encounter a person like this [the individual he was asked about], you must make a distinction between the fact of a person being gay from the fact of being a lobby, because lobbies, all are not good. That is bad. If a person is gay and seeks the Lord and has good will, well who am I to judge them?<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>This remark and others made in the same interview were seen as a change in the tone, but not in the substance of the teaching of the church,<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> which includes opposition to <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1601_05_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1601_05-278">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> Certain <a href="/wiki/Dissent" title="Dissent">dissenting</a> Catholic groups <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality_and_the_Catholic_Church#Differences_from_official_Church_teaching" class="mw-redirect" title="Homosexuality and the Catholic Church">oppose the position of the Catholic Church</a> and seek to change it.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_orders_and_women"><span id="Women_and_clergy"></span>Holy orders and women</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ordination_of_women_in_the_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Ordination of women in the Catholic Church">Ordination of women in the Catholic Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Women_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Women in the Catholic Church">Women in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<p>Women and men religious engage in a variety of occupations, from contemplative prayer, to teaching, to providing health care, to working as missionaries.<sup id="cite_ref-nunsworldwide_244-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nunsworldwide-244">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-280">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Holy_Orders" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Orders">Holy Orders</a> are reserved for men, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_women" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church and women">Catholic women</a> have played diverse roles in the life of the church, with <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute_(Catholic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious institute (Catholic)">religious institutes</a> providing a formal space for their participation and <a href="/wiki/Convent" title="Convent">convents</a> providing spaces for their self-government, prayer and influence through many centuries. Religious sisters and nuns have been extensively involved in developing and running the church's worldwide health and education service networks.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Efforts in support of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_doctrine_on_the_ordination_of_women" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church doctrine on the ordination of women">ordination of women</a> to the priesthood led to several rulings by the Roman Curia or Popes against the proposal, as in <i><a href="/wiki/Inter_Insigniores" title="Inter Insigniores">Declaration on the Question of the Admission of Women to the Ministerial Priesthood</a></i> (1976), <i><a href="/wiki/Mulieris_Dignitatem" class="mw-redirect" title="Mulieris Dignitatem">Mulieris Dignitatem</a></i> (1988) and <i><a href="/wiki/Ordinatio_sacerdotalis" title="Ordinatio sacerdotalis">Ordinatio sacerdotalis</a></i> (1994). According to the latest ruling, found in <i>Ordinatio sacerdotalis</i>, <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> affirmed that the Catholic Church "does not consider herself authorized to admit women to priestly ordination".<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> In defiance of these rulings, opposition groups such as <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Womenpriests" title="Roman Catholic Womenpriests">Roman Catholic Womenpriests</a> have performed ceremonies they affirm as sacramental ordinations (with, reputedly, an ordaining male Catholic bishop in the first few instances) which, according to <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">canon law</a>, are both illicit and invalid and considered mere <i>simulations</i><sup id="cite_ref-cann1379_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cann1379-283">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> of the sacrament of ordination.<sup id="cite_ref-RCWP_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RCWP-284">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;note 13&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Doctrine_of_the_Faith" title="Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith">Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith</a> responded by issuing a statement clarifying that any Catholic bishops involved in ordination ceremonies for women, as well as the women themselves if they were Catholic, would automatically receive the penalty of <a href="/wiki/Excommunication" title="Excommunication">excommunication</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Latae_sententiae" title="Latae sententiae">latae sententiae</a></i>, literally "with the sentence already applied", i.e. automatically), citing canon 1378 of <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">canon law</a> and other church laws.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_abuse_cases">Sexual abuse cases</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_cases" title="Catholic Church sexual abuse cases">Catholic Church sexual abuse cases</a></div>
<p>From the 1990s, the issue of <a href="/wiki/Sexual_abuse_of_minors" class="mw-redirect" title="Sexual abuse of minors">sexual abuse of minors</a> by Catholic clergy and other church members has become the subject of civil litigation, criminal prosecution, media coverage and public debate in <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sex_abuse_cases_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church sex abuse cases by country">countries around the world</a>. The Catholic Church has been criticised for its handling of abuse complaints when it became known that some bishops had shielded accused priests, transferring them to other pastoral assignments where some continued to commit sexual offences.
</p><p>In response to the scandal, formal procedures have been established to help prevent abuse, encourage the reporting of any abuse that occurs and to handle such reports promptly, although groups representing victims have disputed their effectiveness.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> In 2014, Pope Francis instituted the <a href="/wiki/Pontifical_Commission_for_the_Protection_of_Minors" title="Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors">Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors</a> for the safeguarding of minors.<sup id="cite_ref-Bollettino_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bollettino-288">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="History of the Catholic Church">History of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_early_Christianity" title="History of early Christianity">History of early Christianity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_early_Christianity" title="Historiography of early Christianity">Historiography of early Christianity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_(Capilla_Sixtina,_1481-82).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Painting a haloed Jesus Christ passing keys to a kneeling man." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/280px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/420px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/560px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3055" data-file-height="1893" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_(Capilla_Sixtina,_1481-82).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">fresco</a> (1481–82) by <a href="/wiki/Pietro_Perugino" title="Pietro Perugino">Pietro Perugino</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sistine_Chapel" title="Sistine Chapel">Sistine Chapel</a> shows Jesus giving the <a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">keys of heaven</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/220px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/330px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/440px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5193" data-file-height="2926" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Supper_(Leonardo_da_Vinci)" class="mw-redirect" title="The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)"><i>The Last Supper</i></a>, a late 1490s mural painting by <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, depicting the last supper of Jesus and his <a href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve apostles">twelve apostles</a> on the eve of his <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion" title="Crucifixion">crucifixion</a>. Most apostles are buried in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, including Saint Peter.</div></div></div>
<p>The Christian religion is based on the teachings of <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus Christ">Jesus Christ</a>, who lived and preached in the 1st century AD in the province of <a href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Judea</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic doctrine</a> teaches that the contemporary Catholic Church is the continuation of this early Christian community established by Jesus.<sup id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-7">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup> Christianity spread throughout the early Roman Empire, despite persecutions due to conflicts with the pagan state religion. <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Constantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Constantine">Emperor Constantine</a> legalised the practice of Christianity in 313, and it became the state religion in 380. Germanic invaders of Roman territory in the 5th and 6th centuries, many of whom had previously adopted <a href="/wiki/Arian_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Arian Christianity">Arian Christianity</a>, eventually adopted Catholicism to ally themselves with the papacy and the monasteries.
</p><p>In the 7th and 8th centuries, expanding <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim conquests">Muslim conquests</a> following the advent of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> led to an Arab domination of the Mediterranean that severed political connections between that area and northern Europe, and weakened cultural connections between <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_opposition_to_papal_supremacy" title="Eastern Orthodox opposition to papal supremacy">Conflicts involving authority in the church</a>, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_differences_between_the_Catholic_Church_and_the_Eastern_Orthodox_Church#Papal_authority" title="Ecclesiastical differences between the Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church">authority of the Bishop of Rome</a> finally culminated in the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> in the 11th century, splitting the church into the Catholic and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> Churches. Earlier splits within the church occurred after the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> (431) and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> (451). However, a few Eastern Churches remained in <a href="/wiki/Communion_(Christian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Communion (Christian)">communion</a> with Rome, and portions of some others established communion in the 15th century and later, forming what are called the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>.
</p><p>Early monasteries throughout Europe helped preserve Greek and Roman <a href="/wiki/Classical_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Classical civilisation">classical civilisation</a>. The church eventually became the dominant influence in Western civilisation into the modern age. Many <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> figures were sponsored by the church. The 16th century, however, began to see challenges to the church, in particular to its religious authority, by figures in the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>, as well as in the 17th century by secular intellectuals in the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a>. Concurrently, Spanish and Portuguese explorers and missionaries spread the church's influence through Africa, Asia, and the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>.
</p><p>In 1870, the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> declared the dogma of <a href="/wiki/Papal_infallibility" title="Papal infallibility">papal infallibility</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> annexed the city of Rome, the last portion of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a> to be incorporated into the new nation. In the 20th century, anti-clerical governments around the world, including Mexico and Spain, persecuted or executed thousands of clerics and laypersons. In the Second World War, the church condemned Nazism, and protected hundreds of thousands of Jews from the <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" class="mw-redirect" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>; its efforts, however, have been criticised as inadequate. After the war, freedom of religion was severely restricted in the <a href="/wiki/Communist" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist">Communist</a> countries newly aligned with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, several of which had large Catholic populations.
</p><p>In the 1960s, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> led to reforms of the church's liturgy and practices, described as "opening the windows" by defenders, but criticised by <a href="/wiki/Traditionalist_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Traditionalist Catholic">traditionalist Catholics</a>. In the face of increased criticism from both within and without, the church has upheld or reaffirmed at various times controversial doctrinal positions regarding sexuality and gender, including limiting clergy to males, and moral exhortations against <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Contraception" class="mw-redirect" title="Contraception">contraception</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_sexual_activity#Sex_outside_of_marriage" title="Human sexual activity">sexual activity</a> outside of marriage, remarriage following <a href="/wiki/Divorce" title="Divorce">divorce</a> without <a href="/wiki/Annulment" title="Annulment">annulment</a>, and against <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apostolic_era_and_papacy">Apostolic era and papacy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic Age">Apostolic Age</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/220px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/330px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/440px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jesus' commission to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, in particular the <a href="/wiki/Gospels" class="mw-redirect" title="Gospels">Gospels</a>, records Jesus' activities and teaching, his appointment of the <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve Apostles">twelve Apostles</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Apostles" title="Apostles">Apostles</a>, instructing them to continue his work.<sup id="cite_ref-bokenkotter30_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bokenkotter30-115">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Kreeft98O_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft98O-289">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> The book <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Apostles" class="mw-redirect" title="Acts of Apostles">Acts of Apostles</a>, tells of the founding of the Christian church and the spread of its message to the Roman empire.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup>  The Catholic Church teaches that its public ministry began on <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, occurring fifty days following the date Christ is believed to have <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Resurrection of Christ">resurrected</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Barry48_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry48-116">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> At Pentecost, the Apostles are believed to have received the Holy Spirit, preparing them for their mission in leading the church.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> The Catholic Church teaches that the <a href="/wiki/College_of_bishops" class="mw-redirect" title="College of bishops">college of bishops</a>, led by the <a href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Bishop of Rome">Bishop of Rome</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">successors</a> to the Apostles.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the account of the <a href="/wiki/Confession_of_Peter" title="Confession of Peter">Confession of Peter</a> found in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a>, Christ designates Peter as the "rock" upon which Christ's church will be built.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> The Catholic Church considers the Bishop of Rome, the pope, to be the successor to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> Some scholars state Peter was the first Bishop of Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-JoyceCE1913_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JoyceCE1913-297">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;note 14&#93;</a></sup> Others say that the institution of the papacy is not dependent on the idea that Peter was Bishop of Rome or even on his ever having been in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> Many scholars hold that a church structure of plural presbyters/bishops persisted in Rome until the mid-2nd century, when the structure of a single bishop and plural presbyters was adopted,<sup id="cite_ref-REB_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REB-300">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> and that later writers retrospectively applied the term "bishop of Rome" to the most prominent members of the clergy in the earlier period and also to Peter himself.<sup id="cite_ref-REB_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REB-300">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> On this basis, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Cullmann" title="Oscar Cullmann">Oscar Cullmann</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Henry_Chadwick_(theologian)" title="Henry Chadwick (theologian)">Henry Chadwick</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bart_D._Ehrman" title="Bart D. Ehrman">Bart D. Ehrman</a><sup id="cite_ref-ehrman_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ehrman-303">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> question whether there was a formal link between Peter and the modern papacy. <a href="/wiki/Raymond_E._Brown" title="Raymond E. Brown">Raymond E. Brown</a> also says that it is anachronistic to speak of Peter in terms of local bishop of Rome, but that Christians of that period would have looked on Peter as having "roles that would contribute in an essential way to the development of the role of the papacy in the subsequent church". These roles, Brown says, "contributed enormously to seeing the bishop of Rome, the bishop of the city where Peter died, and where Paul witnessed to the truth of Christ, as the successor of Peter in care for the church universal".<sup id="cite_ref-REB_300-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REB-300">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity_and_Roman_Empire">Antiquity and Roman Empire</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Early_centers_of_Christianity" title="Early centers of Christianity">Early centers of Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">Pentarchy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_heresies" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Christian heresies">List of Christian heresies</a></div>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding:0.4em 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg" class="image"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" decoding="async" width="25" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/38px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/50px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="815" data-file-height="1105" /></a></td></tr><tr><td style="padding-top:0.2em;line-height:1.2em">Part of a <a href="/wiki/Category:Ecumenical_councils" title="Category:Ecumenical councils">series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;padding-top:0;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_ecumenical_councils" title="Catholic ecumenical councils">Ecumenical councils</a><br />of the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Catholic Church</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0.2em 0 0.4em"><a href="/wiki/File:Council_Trent.jpg" class="image" title="A Renaissance print depicting the Council of Trent"><img alt="A Renaissance print depicting the Council of Trent" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg/170px-Council_Trent.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="118" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg/255px-Council_Trent.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg 2x" data-file-width="323" data-file-height="224" /></a><div style="padding-top:0.2em;line-height:1.2em">Renaissance depiction of the Council of Trent</div></td></tr><tr><th style="padding:0.1em;background-color:gold">
