<li><a href="/wiki/1989_murders_of_Jesuits_in_El_Salvador" title="1989 murders of Jesuits in El Salvador">1989 murders of Jesuits</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="hlist" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left"><a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/Religious_violence_in_Nigeria" title="Religious violence in Nigeria">Religious violence in Nigeria</a></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="hlist" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left"><a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Stanley_Rother" title="Stanley Rother">Stanley Rother</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<a href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg" class="image"><img alt="046CupolaSPietro.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" decoding="async" width="16" height="12" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism&#32;portal</a></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template:Persecutions of the Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template talk:Persecutions of the Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_(Brazil).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/220px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/330px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/440px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3253" data-file-height="2441" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_(Brazil).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ruins of the <a href="/wiki/Jesuit_Reduction" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesuit Reduction">Jesuit Reduction</a> at <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es" title="São Miguel das Missões">São Miguel das Missões</a> in Brazil</div></div></div><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a></div>
<p>From the 17th century onward, the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> questioned the power and influence of the Catholic Church over Western society.<sup id="cite_ref-Pollard8_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pollard8-352">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> In the 18th century, writers such as <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A9distes" title="Encyclopédistes">Encyclopédistes</a></i> wrote biting critiques of both religion and the Catholic Church. One target of their criticism was the 1685 <a href="/wiki/Revocation_of_the_Edict_of_Nantes" class="mw-redirect" title="Revocation of the Edict of Nantes">revocation of the Edict of Nantes</a> by King <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV of France</a>, which ended a century-long policy of religious toleration of Protestant Huguenots. As the papacy resisted pushes for <a href="/wiki/Gallicanism" title="Gallicanism">Gallicanism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> of 1789 shifted power to the state, caused the destruction of churches, the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Cult_of_Reason" title="Cult of Reason">Cult of Reason</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Bokenkotter285_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bokenkotter285-353">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> and the martyrdom of <a href="/wiki/Martyrs_of_Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Martyrs of Compiègne">nuns</a> during the <i><a href="/wiki/Reign_of_Terror" title="Reign of Terror">Reign of Terror</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> In 1798, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleon I of France">Napoleon Bonaparte</a>'s General <a href="/wiki/Louis-Alexandre_Berthier" title="Louis-Alexandre Berthier">Louis-Alexandre Berthier</a> invaded the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a>, imprisoning <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_VI" title="Pope Pius VI">Pope Pius VI</a>, who died in captivity. Napoleon later re-established the Catholic Church in France through the <a href="/wiki/Concordat_of_1801" title="Concordat of 1801">Concordat of 1801</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Collins176_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collins176-355">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup> The end of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> brought Catholic revival and the return of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1854, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a>, with the support of the overwhelming majority of Catholic bishops, whom he had consulted from 1851 to 1853, proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">Immaculate Conception</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">Dogma in the Catholic Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup> In 1870, the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> affirmed the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Papal_infallibility" title="Papal infallibility">papal infallibility</a> when exercised in specifically defined pronouncements,<sup id="cite_ref-Leith_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leith-358">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Duffy232_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Duffy232-359">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> striking a blow to the rival position of <a href="/wiki/Conciliar_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Conciliar Church">conciliarism</a>. Controversy over this and other issues resulted in a breakaway movement called the <a href="/wiki/Old_Catholic_Church#Impact_of_the_First_Vatican_Council:_second_stage" title="Old Catholic Church">Old Catholic Church</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch-360">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italian unification</a> of the 1860s incorporated the Papal States, including Rome itself from 1870, into the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a>, thus ending the papacy's <a href="/wiki/Temporal_power_(papal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Temporal power (papal)">temporal power</a>. In response, Pope Pius IX excommunicated <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Victor Emmanuel II">King Victor Emmanuel II</a>, refused payment for the land, and rejected the Italian <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Guarantees" title="Law of Guarantees">Law of Guarantees</a>, which granted him special privileges. To avoid placing himself in visible subjection to the Italian authorities, he remained a "<a href="/wiki/Prisoner_in_the_Vatican" title="Prisoner in the Vatican">prisoner in the Vatican</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> This stand-off, which was spoken of as the <i><a href="/wiki/Roman_Question" title="Roman Question">Roman Question</a></i>, was resolved by the 1929 <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaties" class="mw-redirect" title="Lateran Treaties">Lateran Treaties</a>, whereby the Holy See acknowledged Italian sovereignty over the former Papal States in return for payment and Italy's recognition of papal sovereignty over <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> as a new sovereign and independent state.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/220px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/330px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/440px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg 2x" data-file-width="633" data-file-height="455" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Members of the Canadian <a href="/wiki/Royal_22e_Regiment" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal 22e Regiment">Royal 22<sup>e</sup> Regiment</a> in audience with <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a>, following the <a href="/wiki/Liberation_of_Rome" class="mw-redirect" title="Liberation of Rome">Liberation of Rome</a> in 1944 during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_20th_century" title="Catholic Church in the 20th century">Catholic Church in the 20th century</a></div>
<p>A number of <a href="/wiki/Anti-clerical" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-clerical">anti-clerical</a> governments emerged in the 20th century.
</p><p>The 1926 <a href="/wiki/Calles_Law" title="Calles Law">Calles Law</a> separating church and state in Mexico led to the <a href="/wiki/Cristero_War" title="Cristero War">Cristero War</a><sup id="cite_ref-Chadwick264_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick264-363">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> in which more than 3,000&#160;priests were exiled or assassinated,<sup id="cite_ref-Scheina_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scheina-364">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> churches desecrated, services mocked, nuns raped, and captured priests shot.<sup id="cite_ref-Chadwick264_363-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick264-363">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> Following the 1917 <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, persecution of the church and Catholics in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> continued into the 1930s, with the execution and exiling of clerics, monks and laymen, the confiscation of religious implements, and closure of churches.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Riasanovsky_634_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Riasanovsky_634-366">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> In the 1936–39 <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a>, the Catholic hierarchy allied with <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Franco's</a> <a href="/wiki/Spanish_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish State">Nationalists</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Popular_Front_(Spain)" title="Popular Front (Spain)">Popular Front</a> government,<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> citing as justification <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Spain)" title="Red Terror (Spain)">Republican violence</a> against the church.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> referred to these three countries as a "terrible triangle".<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-divinired_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-divinired-371">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After violations of the 1933 <a href="/wiki/Reichskonkordat" title="Reichskonkordat">Reichskonkordat</a> between the church and <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> issued the 1937 encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Mit_brennender_Sorge" title="Mit brennender Sorge">Mit brennender Sorge</a></i>, which publicly condemned the Nazis' persecution of the church and their ideology of <a href="/wiki/Modern_Paganism" title="Modern Paganism">neo-paganism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supremacism" title="Supremacism">racial superiority</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rhodes182_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes182-372">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rhodes197_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes197-373">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rhodes204_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes204-374">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> The church condemned the 1939 <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a> that started <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> and other subsequent wartime Nazi invasions.<sup id="cite_ref-Cook983_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cook983-375">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> Thousands of Catholic priests, nuns and brothers were imprisoned and murdered throughout the countries occupied by the Nazis, including Saints <a href="/wiki/Maximilian_Kolbe" title="Maximilian Kolbe">Maximilian Kolbe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edith_Stein" title="Edith Stein">Edith Stein</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> has been credited with helping to <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII_and_the_Holocaust" title="Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust">save hundreds of thousands of Jews</a> during the <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">Holocaust</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Deák_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Deák-378">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> the church has also been accused of having encouraged centuries of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_and_antisemitism" class="mw-redirect" title="Christianity and antisemitism">antisemitism</a> by its teachings<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> and not doing enough to stop Nazi atrocities.<sup id="cite_ref-Phayer_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Phayer-380">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Post-war" title="Post-war">post-war</a> period, Communist governments in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> severely restricted religious freedoms.<sup id="cite_ref-communist_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-communist-381">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> Although some priests and religious people collaborated with Communist regimes,<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> many others were imprisoned, deported, or executed. The church was an important player in the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">fall of Communism</a> in Europe, particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People&#39;s Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1949, the Communist victory in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> led to the expulsion of all foreign missionaries.<sup id="cite_ref-Bokenkotter357_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bokenkotter357-384">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> The new government also created the <a href="/wiki/Patriotic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Patriotic Church">Patriotic Church</a> and appointed its bishops. These appointments were initially rejected by Rome, before many of them were accepted.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> In the 1960s during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, the Chinese Communists closed all religious establishments. When Chinese churches eventually reopened, they remained under the control of the Patriotic Church. Many Catholic pastors and priests continued to be sent to prison for refusing to renounce allegiance to Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Vatican_Council">Second Vatican Council</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/220px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/330px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/440px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1328" data-file-height="1328" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bishops listen during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_since_1962" title="History of the Catholic Church since 1962">History of the Catholic Church since 1962</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Spirit_of_Vatican_II" title="Spirit of Vatican II">Spirit of Vatican II</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> (1962–1965) introduced the most significant changes to Catholic practices since the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a>, four centuries before.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> Initiated by <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a>, this ecumenical council modernised the practices of the Catholic Church, allowing the Mass to be said in the <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> (local language) and encouraging "fully conscious, and active participation in liturgical celebrations".<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> It intended to engage the church more closely with the present world (<i><a href="/wiki/Aggiornamento" title="Aggiornamento">aggiornamento</a></i>), which was described by its advocates as an "opening of the windows".<sup id="cite_ref-Duffy272_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Duffy272-389">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> In addition to changes in the liturgy, it led to changes to the church's approach to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_ecumenism" title="Catholic Church and ecumenism">ecumenism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> and a call to improved relations with non-Christian religions, especially <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, in its document <i><a href="/wiki/Nostra_aetate" title="Nostra aetate">Nostra aetate</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-NOSTRA_AETATE_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOSTRA_AETATE-391">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The council, however, generated significant controversy in implementing its reforms: proponents of the "<a href="/wiki/Spirit_of_Vatican_II" title="Spirit of Vatican II">Spirit of Vatican II</a>" such as Swiss theologian <a href="/wiki/Hans_K%C3%BCng" title="Hans Küng">Hans Küng</a> said that Vatican II had "not gone far enough" to change church policies.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traditionalist_Catholics" class="mw-redirect" title="Traditionalist Catholics">Traditionalist Catholics</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Archbishop" title="Archbishop">Archbishop</a> <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Lefebvre" title="Marcel Lefebvre">Marcel Lefebvre</a>, however, strongly criticised the council, arguing that its liturgical reforms led "to the destruction of the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass and the sacraments", among other issues.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Several teachings of the Catholic Church came under increased scrutiny both concurrent with and following the council; among those teachings was the church's teaching regarding the immorality of <a href="/wiki/Birth_control" title="Birth control">contraception</a>. The recent introduction of <a href="/wiki/Hormonal_contraception" title="Hormonal contraception">hormonal contraception</a> (including "the pill"), which were believed by some to be morally different from previous methods, prompted John XXIII to form a committee to advise him of the moral and theological issues with the new method.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> later expanded the committee's scope to freely examine all methods, and the committee's unreleased final report was rumoured to suggest permitting at least some methods of contraception. Paul did not agree with the arguments presented, and eventually issued <i><a href="/wiki/Humanae_vitae" title="Humanae vitae">Humanae vitae</a></i>, saying that it upheld the constant teaching of the church against contraception. It expressly included hormonal methods as prohibited.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;note 15&#93;</a></sup> This document generated a largely negative response from many Catholics.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (September 2016)">from whom?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup><sup id="cite_ref-HV_then_now_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HV_then_now-397">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="John_Paul_II">John Paul II</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg/220px-President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg/330px-President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg/440px-President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg 2x" data-file-width="494" data-file-height="336" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:President_and_Mrs._Reagan_meet_Pope_John_Paul_II_1982.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> was credited as a major influence to the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_communism" class="mw-redirect" title="Fall of communism">fall of communism</a>. Here with U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> and his wife, <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">Nancy</a>, in 1982.</div></div></div><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a></div>
<p>In 1978, <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a>, formerly <a href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Krak%C3%B3w" title="Archbishop of Kraków">Archbishop of Kraków</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People&#39;s Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>, became the first non-Italian pope in 455 years. His 26 1/2-year <a href="/wiki/Pontificate" title="Pontificate">pontificate</a> was one of the longest in history.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, the president of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, credited the Polish pope with hastening the fall of Communism in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>John Paul sought to evangelise an increasingly <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular world</a>. He instituted <a href="/wiki/World_Youth_Day" title="World Youth Day">World Youth Day</a> as a "worldwide encounter with the pope" for young people; it is now held every two to three years.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup> He travelled more than any other pope, visiting 129 countries,<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> and used television and radio as means of spreading the church's teachings. He also emphasised the <a href="/wiki/Dignity_of_labour" title="Dignity of labour">dignity of work</a> and natural rights of labourers to have <a href="/wiki/Living_wage" title="Living wage">fair wages</a> and safe conditions in <i><a href="/wiki/Laborem_exercens" title="Laborem exercens">Laborem exercens</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> He emphasised several church teachings, including moral exhortations against <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia" title="Euthanasia">euthanasia</a>, and against widespread use of the <a href="/wiki/Death_penalty" class="mw-redirect" title="Death penalty">death penalty</a>, in <i><a href="/wiki/Evangelium_Vitae" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelium Vitae">Evangelium Vitae</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From the late 20th century, the Catholic Church has been <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Criticism of the Catholic Church">criticised</a> for its doctrines on <a href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">sexuality</a>, its inability to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_doctrine_on_the_ordination_of_women" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church doctrine on the ordination of women">ordain women</a>, and its handling of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_cases" title="Catholic Church sexual abuse cases">sexual abuse cases</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg/220px-Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg/330px-Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg/440px-Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="865" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Benoit_xvi_octobre_2008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>, who strengthened the relationship between the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic Church and art">Catholic Church and art</a>, has been called "the pope of <a href="/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics">aesthetics</a>".</div></div></div>
<p>In 2005, following the death of John Paul II, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>, head of the <a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Doctrine_of_the_Faith" title="Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith">Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith</a> under John Paul, was elected. He was known for upholding traditional <a href="/wiki/Christian_values" title="Christian values">Christian values</a> against <a href="/wiki/Secularisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Secularisation">secularisation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> and for liberalising use of the <a href="/wiki/Tridentine_Mass" title="Tridentine Mass">Tridentine Mass</a> as found in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Missal" title="Roman Missal">Roman Missal</a> of 1962.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> In 2012, the 50th anniversary of Vatican II, an assembly of the <a href="/wiki/Synod_of_Bishops_(Catholic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Synod of Bishops (Catholic)">Synod of Bishops</a> discussed re-evangelising <a href="/wiki/Lapsed_Catholic" title="Lapsed Catholic">lapsed Catholics</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Summary_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Summary-406">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> Citing the frailties of advanced age, Benedict <a href="/wiki/Resignation_of_Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Resignation of Pope Benedict XVI">resigned</a> in 2013, the first pope to do so in nearly 600 years.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pope_Francis">Pope Francis</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_(1).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG/220px-Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG/330px-Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG/440px-Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_%281%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pope_Franciscus_%26_Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_in_the_Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre_in_Jerusalem_(1).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a>, noted for his ecumencial efforts, meeting <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_of_Constantinople" class="mw-redirect" title="Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople">Patriarch Bartholomew I</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, during <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a> in 2014</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a>, the current pope of the Catholic Church, succeeded Pope Benedict XVI in 2013 as the first pope from the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, the first from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, and the first Pope from outside Europe since the Syrian <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_III" title="Pope Gregory III">Gregory III</a>, who reigned in the 8th century. Pope Francis has been noted for his <a href="/wiki/Humility" title="Humility">humility</a>, emphasis on God's mercy, concern for the <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Environment_(biophysical)" class="mw-redirect" title="Environment (biophysical)">environment</a>, as well as his commitment to <a href="/wiki/Interfaith_dialogue" title="Interfaith dialogue">interfaith dialogue</a>. He is credited with having a less formal approach to the papacy than his predecessors.
</p><p>Pope Francis is recognised for his efforts "to further close the nearly 1,000-year estrangement with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Churches</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-orthodox_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orthodox-408">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> His installation was attended by <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_of_Constantinople" class="mw-redirect" title="Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople">Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-patriarch_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patriarch-409">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> the first time since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054 that the Eastern Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople</a> has attended a papal installation.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> On 12 February 2016, Pope Francis and <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Kirill_of_Moscow" title="Patriarch Kirill of Moscow">Patriarch Kirill of Moscow</a>, head of the largest Eastern Orthodox church, met in <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">Havana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, issuing <a href="/wiki/Joint_Declaration_of_Pope_Francis_and_Patriarch_Kirill" title="Joint Declaration of Pope Francis and Patriarch Kirill">a joint declaration</a> calling for restored Christian unity between the two churches. This was reported as the first such high-level meeting between the two churches since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Third_Extraordinary_General_Assembly_of_the_Synod_of_Bishops" title="Third Extraordinary General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops">Third Extraordinary General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops</a> addressed the church's ministry towards families and marriages and to Catholics in "irregular" relationships, such as those who <a href="/wiki/Divorce" title="Divorce">divorced</a> and remarried outside of the church without a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_nullity" title="Declaration of nullity">declaration of nullity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup> While welcomed by some, it was criticised by some for perceived ambiguity, provoking controversies among individual representatives of differing perspectives.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017 during a visit in <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, Pope Francis reestablished mutual recognition of baptism with the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Orthodox Church</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

</p>

</div>
<table role="presentation" class="metadata mbox-small wikipedia-books" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">

<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/30px-Office-book.svg.png" decoding="async" width="30" height="30" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/45px-Office-book.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/60px-Office-book.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="48" data-file-height="48" /></td>

</tbody></table>

<li><a href="/wiki/Role_of_the_Christianity_in_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Role of the Christianity in civilisation">Role of the Christianity in civilisation</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While the Catholic Church considers itself to be the authentic continuation of the Christian community founded by Jesus Christ, it teaches that other Christian churches and communities can be in an imperfect communion with the Catholic Church.<sup id="cite_ref-note1cite1_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-note1cite1-9">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-note1cite2_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-note1cite2-10">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Quote of St Ignatius to the Smyrnaeans (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;110 AD</span>): "Wheresoever the bishop shall appear, there let the people be, even as where Jesus may be, there is the universal [katholike] Church."<sup id="cite_ref-CathEnc1910_Catholic_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CathEnc1910_Catholic-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-RCHolySeeR-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-RCHolySeeR_30-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Examples uses of "Roman Catholic" by the Holy See: the encyclicals <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xi_enc_31121929_divini-illius-magistri_en.html"><i>Divini Illius Magistri</i></a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100923233927/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xi_enc_31121929_divini-illius-magistri_en.html">Archived</a> 23 September 2010 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xii_enc_12081950_humani-generis_en.html"><i>Humani generis</i></a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120419021937/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xii_enc_12081950_humani-generis_en.html">Archived</a> 19 April 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a>; joint declarations signed by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> with <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/speeches/2006/november/documents/hf_ben-xvi_spe_20061123_common-decl_en.html">Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams on 23 November 2006</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130302070228/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/speeches/2006/november/documents/hf_ben-xvi_spe_20061123_common-decl_en.html">Archived</a> 2 March 2013 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> and <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ewtn.com/library/PAPALDOC/b16bart1decl.htm">Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople on 30 November 2006.</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-RCbishop-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-RCbishop_31-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Example use of "Roman" Catholic by a bishop's conference: <i>The Baltimore Catechism</i>, an official catechism authorised by the Catholic bishops of the United States, states: "That is why we are called Roman Catholics; to show that we are united to the real successor of St Peter" (Question 118) and refers to the church as the "Roman Catholic Church" under Questions 114 and 131 (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cin.org/users/james/ebooks/master/baltimore/bcreed09.htm">Baltimore Catechism).</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The last resignation occurred on 28 February 2013, when <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> retired, citing ill health in his advanced age. The next most recent resignation occurred in 1415, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Constance" title="Council of Constance">Council of Constance</a>'s resolution of the <a href="/wiki/Avignon_Papacy" title="Avignon Papacy">Avignon Papacy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-duffy415_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-duffy415-46">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 1992, the Vatican clarified the 1983 Code of Canon Law removed the requirement that altar servers be male; permission to use female altar servers within a diocese is at the discretion of the bishop.<sup id="cite_ref-Apostalicae86_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Apostalicae86-84">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-155">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Other councils that addressed the sacraments include the <a href="/wiki/Second_Council_of_Lyon" title="Second Council of Lyon">Second Council of Lyon</a> (1274); <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Florence" title="Council of Florence">Council of Florence</a> (1439); as well as the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> (1547)<sup id="cite_ref-1113_14_154-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1113_14-154">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-185">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">For an outline of the Eucharistic liturgy in the Roman Rite, see the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church#Roman_Rite_of_Mass" title="Catholic Church">side bar</a> in the "Worship and liturgy".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-211"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-211">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Marriages involving unbaptised individuals are considered valid, but not sacramental. While sacramental marriages are insoluble, non-sacramental marriages may be dissolved under certain situations, such as a desire to marry a Catholic, under <a href="/wiki/Pauline_privilege" title="Pauline privilege">Pauline</a> or <a href="/wiki/Petrine_privilege" title="Petrine privilege">Petrine privilege</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Gantley_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gantley-209">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Doors_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Doors-210">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-225"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-225">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Divine Worship variant of the Roman Rite differs from the "Anglican Use" variant, which was introduced in 1980 for the few United States parishes established in accordance with a <a href="/wiki/Pastoral_Provision" title="Pastoral Provision">pastoral provision</a> for former members of the <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_Church_(United_States)" title="Episcopal Church (United States)">Episcopal Church</a> (the American branch of the Anglican Communion). Both uses adapted Anglican liturgical traditions for use within the Catholic Church.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-261"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-261">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">With regard to divorce in the United States, according to the Barna Group, among all who have been married, 33% have been divorced at least once; among American Catholics, 28% (the study did not track religious annulments).<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Regarding use of <a href="/wiki/Natural_family_planning" title="Natural family planning">natural family planning</a>, in 2002, 24% of the U.S. population identified as Catholic,<sup id="cite_ref-adherents_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-adherents-267">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> but according to a 2002 study by the <a href="/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention" title="Centers for Disease Control and Prevention">Centers for Disease Control and Prevention</a>, of sexually active Americans avoiding pregnancy, only 1.5% were using NFP.<sup id="cite_ref-cdc_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cdc-268">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-285"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-285">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Roman Catholic Womanpriests: "The principal consecrating Roman Catholic male bishop who ordained our first women bishops is a bishop with apostolic succession within the Roman Catholic Church in full communion with the pope."<sup id="cite_ref-RCWP_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RCWP-284">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-298"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-298">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Joyce, George (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/The Pope"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/The_Pope">"The Pope"&#160;</a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Pope&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Joyce&amp;rft.aufirst=George&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886058088">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Lock-green.svg/9px-Lock-green.svg.png")no-repeat;background-position:right .1em center}.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg/9px-Lock-gray-alt-2.svg.png")no-repeat;background-position:right .1em center}.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg/9px-Lock-red-alt-2.svg.png")no-repeat;background-position:right .1em center}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png")no-repeat;background-position:right .1em center}.mw-parser-output code.cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:inherit;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#33aa33;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration,.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-right{padding-right:0.2em}</style><br /><i>Regarding Peter as the first Bishop of Rome,</i> "It is not, however, difficult to show that the fact of his [Peter's] bishopric is so well attested as to be historically certain. In considering this point, it will be well to begin with the third century, when references to it become frequent, and work backwards from this point. In the middle of the third century St. Cyprian expressly terms the Roman See the Chair of St. Peter, saying that Cornelius has succeeded to "the place of Fabian which is the place of Peter" (Ep 55:8; cf. 59:14). Firmilian of Caesarea notices that Stephen claimed to decide the controversy regarding rebaptism on the ground that he held the succession from Peter (Cyprian, Ep. 75:17). He does not deny the claim: yet certainly, had he been able, he would have done so. Thus in 250 the Roman episcopate of Peter was admitted by those best able to know the truth, not merely at Rome but in the churches of Africa and of Asia Minor. In the first quarter of the century (about 220) Tertullian (De Pud. 21) mentions Callistus's claim that Peter's power to forgive sins had descended in a special manner to him. Had the Roman Church been merely founded by Peter and not reckoned him as its first bishop, there could have been no ground for such a contention. Tertullian, like Firmilian, had every motive to deny the claim. Moreover, he had himself resided at Rome, and would have been well aware if the idea of a Roman episcopate of Peter had been, as is contended by its opponents, a novelty dating from the first years of the third century, supplanting the older tradition according to which Peter and Paul were co-founders, and Linus first bishop. About the same period, Hippolytus (for Lightfoot is surely right in holding him to be the author of the first part of the "Liberian Catalogue" – "Clement of Rome", 1:259) reckons Peter in the list of Roman bishops...."<sup id="cite_ref-JoyceCE1913_297-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JoyceCE1913-297">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-396"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-396">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While ruling contraception to be prohibited, Pope Paul VI did, however, consider natural family planning methods to be morally permissible if used with just cause.</span>
</li>
</ol></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<ul><li><b>NOTE:</b> <i>CCC</i> stands for <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>. The number following <i>CCC</i> is the paragraph number, of which there are 2865. The numbers cited in the <i><a href="/wiki/Compendium_of_the_Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Compendium of the Catechism of the Catholic Church">Compendium of the CCC</a></i> are question numbers, of which there are 598. Canon law citations from the 1990 <i><a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches</a></i> are labelled "<i>CCEO</i>, Canon xxx", to distinguish from canons of the 1983 <i><a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">Code of Canon Law</a></i>, which are labelled "Canon xxx".</li></ul>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 20em; -webkit-column-width: 20em; column-width: 20em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-Episcopal_Polity-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Episcopal_Polity_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Marshall, Thomas William (1844). <i>Notes of the Episcopal Polity of the Holy Catholic Church</i>. <li id="cite_note-O&#39;CollinsPref-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-O&#39;CollinsPref_6-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-O&#39;CollinsPref_6-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Gerald_O%27Collins" title="Gerald O&#39;Collins">O'Collins</a>, p. v (preface).</span>

<li id="cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_7-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070710201403/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0703923.htm">"Vatican congregation reaffirms truth, oneness of Catholic Church"</a>. Catholic News Service. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0703923.htm">the original</a> on 10 July 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 March</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Vatican+congregation+reaffirms+truth%2C+oneness+of+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.pub=Catholic+News+Service&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.catholicnews.com%2Fdata%2Fstories%2Fcns%2F0703923.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bokenkotter, Thomas (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=DISK1e7JXA8C&amp;pg=PA7"><i>A Concise History of the Catholic Church</i></a>. New York: Doubleday. p.&#160;7. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-307-42348-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-307-42348-1"><bdi>978-0-307-42348-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+History+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=7&amp;rft.pub=Doubleday&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-307-42348-1&amp;rft.aulast=Bokenkotter&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DDISK1e7JXA8C%26pg%3DPA7&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-note1cite1-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-note1cite1_9-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130813100622/http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/cfaith/documents/rc_con_cfaith_doc_20070629_responsa-quaestiones_en.html">"Responses to Some Questions regarding Certain Aspects of the Doctrine of the Church"</a>. Vatican.va. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/cfaith/documents/rc_con_cfaith_doc_20070629_responsa-quaestiones_en.html">the original</a> on 13 August 2013. <q>It is possible, according to Catholic doctrine, to affirm correctly that the Church of Christ is present and operative in the churches and <a href="/wiki/Ecclesial_community" title="Ecclesial community">ecclesial Communities</a> not yet fully in communion with the Catholic Church, on account of the elements of sanctification and truth that are present in them.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Responses+to+Some+Questions+regarding+Certain+Aspects+of+the+Doctrine+of+the+Church&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Froman_curia%2Fcongregations%2Fcfaith%2Fdocuments%2Frc_con_cfaith_doc_20070629_responsa-quaestiones_en.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-note1cite2-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-note1cite2_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">"Declaration on the Unicity and Salvific Universality of Jesus Christ and the Church <i>Dominus Iesus</i> § 17". Vatican.va. <q>Therefore, there exists a single Church of Christ, which subsists in the Catholic Church, governed by the Successor of Peter and by the Bishops in communion with him. The Churches which, while not existing in perfect <i>Koinonia</i> with the Catholic Church, remain united to her by means of the closest bonds, that is, by apostolic succession and a valid Eucharist, are true <a href="/wiki/Particular_Churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Particular Churches">particular Churches</a>. Therefore, the Church of Christ is present and operative also in these Churches, even though they lack full communion with the Catholic Church, since they do not accept the Catholic doctrine of the Primacy, which, according to the will of God, the Bishop of Rome objectively has and exercises over the entire Church. … 'The Christian faithful are therefore not permitted to imagine that the Church of Christ is nothing more than a collection—divided, yet in some way one—of Churches and <a href="/wiki/Ecclesial_community" title="Ecclesial community">ecclesial communities</a>; nor are they free to hold that today the Church of Christ nowhere really exists, and must be considered only as a goal which all Churches and ecclesial communities must strive to reach.'</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Declaration+on+the+Unicity+and+Salvific+Universality+of+Jesus+Christ+and+the+Church+Dominus+Iesus+%C2%A7+17&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Holy Bible: Matthew <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.esv.org/Matthew+16:19">16:19</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CCC_890-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CCC_890_13-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p123a9p4.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 890"</a>. Vatican.va.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+890&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp123a9p4.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p123a9p3.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 835"</a>. Vatican.va. <q>The rich variety of … theological and spiritual heritages proper to the local churches 'unified in a common effort shows all the more resplendently the catholicity of the undivided Church'.(cf. <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a>, Dogmatic Constitution on the Church <a href="/wiki/Lumen_gentium" title="Lumen gentium">Lumen gentium</a>, 23)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+835&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp123a9p3.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gunton2-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Gunton2_15-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Colin Gunton. "Christianity among the Religions in the Encyclopedia of Religion", Religious Studies, Vol. 24, number 1, page 14. In a review of an article from the Encyclopedia of Religion, Gunton writes: "[T]he article [on Catholicism in the encyclopedia] rightly suggests caution, suggesting at the outset that Roman Catholicism is marked by several different doctrinal, theological and liturgical emphases."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p2s2c1a3.htm">CCC, 1322–1327</a>, Vatican.va: "the Eucharist is the sum and summary of our faith"</span>

<li id="cite_note-marian_dogmas-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-marian_dogmas_17-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/resources/mary/general-information/the-four-marian-dogmas/">"The Four Marian Dogmas"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Geopolitics-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Geopolitics_18-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Agnew, John (12 February 2010). <li id="cite_note-CathEnc1910_Catholic-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CathEnc1910_Catholic_22-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CathEnc1910_Catholic_22-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation encyclopaedia"><a href="/wiki/Herbert_Thurston" title="Herbert Thurston">Thurston, Herbert</a> (1908). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03449a.htm">"Catholic"</a>. <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tertullian.org/fathers2/NPNF2-07/Npnf2-07-23.htm">"Cyril of Jerusalem, Lecture XVIII, 26"</a>. Tertullian.org. 6 August 2004<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 August</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Cyril+of+Jerusalem%2C+Lecture+XVIII%2C+26&amp;rft.pub=Tertullian.org&amp;rft.date=2004-08-06&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tertullian.org%2Ffathers2%2FNPNF2-07%2FNpnf2-07-23.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://webu2.upmf-grenoble.fr/Haiti/Cours/Ak/Constitutiones/Thessalonique.htm">Edictum de fide catholica</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Eastern-Orthodoxy">"Eastern Orthodoxy"</a>, <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i> online.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"catholic, adj. and n." <a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a> Online. Oxford University Press, June 2014. Web. 7 August 2014. Excerpt: "After the separation of East and West 'Catholic' was assumed as its descriptive epithet by the Western or Latin Church, as 'Orthodox' was by the Eastern or Greek. At the Reformation the term 'Catholic' was claimed as its exclusive right by the body remaining under the Roman obedience, in opposition to the 'Protestant' or 'Reformed' National Churches. These, however, also retained the term, giving it, for the most part, a wider and more ideal or absolute sense, as the attribute of no single community, but only of the whole communion of the saved and saintly in all churches and ages. In England, it was claimed that the Church, even as Reformed, was the national branch of the 'Catholic Church' in its proper historical sense." Note: The full text of the OED definition of "catholic" can be consulted <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Requests_for_mediation/Roman_Catholic_Church/Archive_17" title="Wikipedia talk:Requests for mediation/Roman Catholic Church/Archive 17">here</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-McBrien-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-McBrien_28-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">McBrien, Richard (2008). <i>The Church</i>. Harper Collins. p. xvii. Online version available <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://browseinside.harpercollins.com/index.aspx?isbn13=9780061245213">Browseinside.harpercollins.com</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090827023130/http://browseinside.harpercollins.com/index.aspx?isbn13=9780061245213">Archived</a> 27 August 2009 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>. Quote: "[T]he use of the adjective 'Catholic' as a modifier of 'Church' became divisive only after the East–West Schism... and the Protestant Reformation. … In the former case, the Western Church claimed for itself the title <i>Catholic</i> Church, while the East appropriated the name <i>Orthodox</i> Church. In the latter case, those in communion with the Bishop of Rome retained the adjective "Catholic", while the churches that broke with the Papacy were called <i>Protestant</i>."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/167063">"Roman Catholic, n. and adj"</a></span>. <i>Oxford English Dictionary</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 October</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Oxford+English+Dictionary&amp;rft.atitle=Roman+Catholic%2C+n.+and+adj.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oed.com%2Fview%2FEntry%2F167063&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Vatican. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/">Documents of the II Vatican Council</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20040605190838/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/">Archived</a> 5 June 2004 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>. Retrieved 4 May 2009. Note: The pope's signature appears in the Latin version.</span>

<li id="cite_note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.papalencyclicals.net/councils/ecum20.htm">"Decrees of the First Vatican Council – Papal Encyclicals"</a>. 29 June 1868.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Decrees+of+the+First+Vatican+Council+%E2%80%93+Papal+Encyclicals&amp;rft.date=1868-06-29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.papalencyclicals.net%2Fcouncils%2Fecum20.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://history.hanover.edu/texts/trent/trentall.html">"The Bull of Indiction of the Sacred Oecumenical and General Council of Trent under the Sovereign Pontiff, Paul III."</a> <i>The Council of Trent: The Canons and Decrees of the Sacred and Oecumenical Council of Trent</i>.
