<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/13121a.htm">"Catholic Encyclopedia: Roman Catholic"</a>. <i>www.newadvent.org</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.newadvent.org&amp;rft.atitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia%3A+Roman+Catholic&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newadvent.org%2Fcathen%2F13121a.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ewtn.com/library/ANSWERS/HOWNAME.HTM">"Kenneth D. Whitehead"</a>. <i>www.ewtn.com</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.ewtn.com&amp;rft.atitle=Kenneth+D.+Whitehead&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ewtn.com%2Flibrary%2FANSWERS%2FHOWNAME.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CCC880-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CCC880_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/ccc_toc.htm">"Christ's Faithful – Hierarchy, Laity, Consecrated Life: The episcopal college and its head, the Pope (880–883)"</a>. <i>Catechism of the Catholic Church, Second Edition</i>. Libreria Editrice Vaticana. 2012. <q>'[T]he Roman Pontiff [the Pope], ... has full, supreme, and universal power over the whole Church, a power which he can always exercise unhindered.' 'The college or body of bishops has no authority unless united with the Roman Pontiff, Peter's successor, as its head.' As such, this college has 'supreme and full authority over the universal Church; but this power cannot be exercised without the agreement of the Roman Pontiff.'</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church%2C+Second+Edition&amp;rft.atitle=Christ%27s+Faithful+%E2%80%93+Hierarchy%2C+Laity%2C+Consecrated+Life%3A+The+episcopal+college+and+its+head%2C+the+Pope+%28880%E2%80%93883%29&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fccc_toc.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CEHierarchy-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CEHierarchy_38-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Van Hove, A. (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Hierarchy"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Hierarchy">"Hierarchy"&#160;</a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Hierarchy&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Van+Hove&amp;rft.aufirst=A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> "It is usual to distinguish a twofold hierarchy in the Church, that of <a href="/wiki/Holy_orders" title="Holy orders">order</a> and that of <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_jurisdiction" title="Ecclesiastical jurisdiction">jurisdiction</a>, corresponding to the twofold means of sanctification, grace, which comes to us principally through the sacraments, and good works, which are the fruit of grace."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-section880-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-section880_39-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/_P2A.HTM#PZ">"Christ's Faithful – Hierarchy, Laity, Consecrated Life: The episcopal college and its head, the Pope"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>. Vatican City: Libreria Editrice Vaticana. 1993<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 April</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.atitle=Christ%27s+Faithful+%E2%80%93+Hierarchy%2C+Laity%2C+Consecrated+Life%3A+The+episcopal+college+and+its+head%2C+the+Pope&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2FENG0015%2F_P2A.HTM%23PZ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-60"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-60">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Pink, Thomas. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.firstthings.com/article/2012/08/conscience-and-coercion">"Conscience·and·Coercion"</a>. <i>First·Things</i>. <li id="cite_note-Roberson-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Roberson_65-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Ronald G. Roberson. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cnewa.org/default.aspx?ID=125&amp;pagetypeID=1&amp;sitecode=HQ&amp;pageno=1">"Eastern Catholic Churches Statistics 2010"</a>. <i>CNEWA</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 April</span> 2011</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=CNEWA&amp;rft.atitle=Eastern+Catholic+Churches+Statistics+2010&amp;rft.au=Ronald+G.+Roberson&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnewa.org%2Fdefault.aspx%3FID%3D125%26pagetypeID%3D1%26sitecode%3DHQ%26pageno%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Gunton-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Gunton_66-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Gunton_66-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Colin Gunton. "Christianity among the Religions in the Encyclopedia of Religion", Religious Studies, Vol. 24, number 1, p. 14. In a review of an article from the <i>Encyclopedia of Religion</i>, Gunton writes "...&#160;[T] he article [on Catholicism in the encyclopedia] rightly suggests caution, suggesting at the outset that Roman Catholicism is marked by <i>several different doctrinal and theological emphases</i>."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-OneFaith52-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-OneFaith52_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Barry, p. 52</span>

<li id="cite_note-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-82">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ENG0017/_P1T.HTM">Canon 519</a>". <i>1983 Code of Canon Law</i>. Intratext.com: "The parish priest is the proper clergyman in charge of the congregation of the parish entrusted to him. He exercises the pastoral care of the community entrusted to him under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Diocesan_bishop" title="Diocesan bishop">diocesan bishop</a>, whose ministry of Christ he is called to share, so that for this community he may carry out the offices of teaching, sanctifying and ruling with the cooperation of other priests or deacons and with the assistance of lay members of Christ's faithful, in accordance with the law."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.onlinedigeditions.com/publication/index.php?i=365491&amp;m=&amp;l=&amp;p=1&amp;pre=&amp;ver=html5#{%22page%22:74,%22issue_id%22:365491}">"Laudato Si"</a>. <i>Vermont Catholic</i> (Winter ed.). <b>8</b> (4): 73. 2016–2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-92">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110429072610/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P2A.HTM">"The teaching office"</a>. <i>Catechism of the Catholic Church</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 April</span> 2011</span>. <q>889 in order to preserve the Church in the purity of the faith handed on by the apostles, Christ who is the Truth willed to confer on her a share in his own infallibility.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church&amp;rft.atitle=The+teaching+office&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2FENG0015%2F&#95;_P2A.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Second Vatican Council. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140906031754/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19641121_lumen-gentium_en.html">"Chapter III, paragraph 25"</a>. <i>Lumen Gentium</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P29.HTM">the original</a> on 7 April 2015.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=vatican.va&amp;rft.atitle=Catechism+of+the+Catholic+Church+%E2%80%93+IntraText+%E2%80%93+CCC%2C+811&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2FENG0015%2F&#95;_P29.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kreeft98-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kreeft98_114-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kreeft, p. 98, quote "The fundamental reason for being a Catholic is the historical fact that the Catholic Church was founded by Christ, was God's invention, not man's;... As the Father gave authority to Christ (Jn 5:22; Mt 28:18–20), Christ passed it on to his apostles (Lk 10:16), and they passed it on to the successors they appointed as bishops." (see also Kreeft, p. 980)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-bokenkotter30-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-bokenkotter30_115-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-bokenkotter30_115-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Bokenkotter, p. 30.</span>
</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-OneFaith46-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-OneFaith46_117-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Barry, p. 46</span>

<li id="cite_note-CCC_816-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CCC_816_120-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CCC_816_120-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p123a9p3.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 816"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 December</span> 2014</span>. <q><i>816'</i>:The Second Vatican Council's Decree on Ecumenism explains: "For it is through Christ's Catholic Church alone, which is the universal help toward salvation, that the fullness of the means of salvation can be obtained. It was to the apostolic college alone, of which Peter is the head, that we believe that our Lord entrusted all the blessings of the New Covenant, in order to establish on earth the one Body of Christ into which all those should be fully incorporated who belong in any way to the People of God. [<i><a href="/wiki/Unitatis_redintegratio" title="Unitatis redintegratio">Unitatis redintegratio</a></i> 3 §&#160;5.]</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+816&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp123a9p3.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-137">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Fanning, William (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Baptism"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Baptism">"Baptism"&#160;</a></span>. <li id="cite_note-WilsonFischer2005-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-WilsonFischer2005_138-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Wilson, Douglas; Fischer, Ty (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=zClmDnl3b3EC&amp;pg=PA101"><i>Omnibus II: Church Fathers Through the Reformation</i></a>. Veritas Press. p.&#160;101. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-932168-44-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-932168-44-0"><bdi>978-1-932168-44-0</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>The word 'hallow' means 'saint,' in that 'hallow' is just an alternative form of the word 'holy' ('hallowed be Thy name').</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Omnibus+II%3A+Church+Fathers+Through+the+Reformation&amp;rft.pages=101&amp;rft.pub=Veritas+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-932168-44-0&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Douglas&amp;rft.au=Fischer%2C+Ty&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DzClmDnl3b3EC%26pg%3DPA101&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-DiehlDonnelly2001-139"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-DiehlDonnelly2001_139-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Diehl, Daniel; Donnelly, Mark (2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=-WKyMpNnRWUC&amp;pg=PA13"><i>Medieval Celebrations</i></a>. Stackpole Books. p.&#160;13. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8117-2866-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8117-2866-9"><bdi>978-0-8117-2866-9</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>The word hallow was simply another word for saint.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Medieval+Celebrations&amp;rft.pages=13&amp;rft.pub=Stackpole+Books&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8117-2866-9&amp;rft.aulast=Diehl&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.au=Donnelly%2C+Mark&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D-WKyMpNnRWUC%26pg%3DPA13&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Beatification, in the present discipline, differs from canonization in this: that the former implies (1) a locally restricted, not a universal, permission to venerate, which is (2) a mere permission, and no precept; while canonization implies a universal precept" (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02364b.htm">Beccari, Camillo. "Beatification and Canonization".</a> <i>The Catholic Encyclopedia</i>. Vol. 2. New York, New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. Accessed 27 May 2009.).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-141">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Carroll, Michael P. <li id="cite_note-159"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-159">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Herbermann, Charles, ed. (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Sacraments"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Sacraments">"Sacraments"&#160;</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Sacraments&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CoCC291-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CoCC291_160-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CoCC291_160-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">"<i>CoCC</i> 291". Vatican.va. <q>To receive Holy Communion one must be fully incorporated into the Catholic Church and be in the state of grace, that is, not conscious of being in mortal sin. Anyone who is conscious of having committed a grave sin must first receive the sacrament of Reconciliation before going to Communion. Also important for those receiving Holy Communion are a spirit of recollection and prayer, observance of the fast prescribed by the Church, and an appropriate disposition of the body (gestures and dress) as a sign of respect for Christ.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=CoCC+291&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-165"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-165">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110628185335/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P42.HTM">"<i>CCC</i>, 1400"</a>. <li id="cite_note-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-184">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Pohle, Joseph (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/The Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/The_Real_Presence_of_Christ_in_the_Eucharist">"The Real Presence of Christ in the Eucharist"&#160;</a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Real+Presence+of+Christ+in+the+Eucharist&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Pohle&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-186">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150101045530/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P41.HTM">"<i>CCC</i>, 1365–1372"</a>. Vatican.va. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P41.HTM">the original</a> on 1 January 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 June</span> 2011</span>. <q><b>1365</b> Because it is the memorial of Christ's Passover, the Eucharist is also a sacrifice, thus, in the ritual text of the Mass, the priest asks of the congregation present, "Pray, brothers and sisters, that this my sacrifice and yours may be acceptable to God, the Almighty Father." the sacrificial character of the Eucharist is manifested in the very words of institution: "This is my body which is given for you" and "This cup which is poured out for you is the New Covenant in my blood." [Lk 22:19–20.] In the Eucharist Christ gives us the very body which he gave up for us on the cross, the very blood which he "poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins." [Mt 26:28.]</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1365%E2%80%931372&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2FENG0015%2F&#95;_P41.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ccc1392-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ccc1392_187-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/ccc_toc.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1392–1395"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">23 November</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1392%E2%80%931395&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fccc_toc.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-CCL1037-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CCL1037_203-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P3R.HTM">Canon 1037</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080218110036/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P3R.HTM">Archived</a> 18 February 2008 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, Catholic Church Canon Law. <li id="cite_note-208"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-208">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p2s2c3a7.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1601,1614"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>The matrimonial covenant, by which a man and a woman establish between themselves a partnership of the whole of life, is by its nature ordered toward the good of the spouses and the procreation and education of offspring; this covenant between baptised persons has been raised by Christ the Lord to the dignity of a sacrament.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1601%2C1614&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp2s2c3a7.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-1200_09-214"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1200_09_214-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/ccc_toc.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1200–1209"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 August</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1200%E2%80%931209&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fccc_toc.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CCEO28-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CCEO28_215-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ENG1199/__PS.HTM">"<i>CCEO</i>, Canon 28 §&#160;1"</a>. Vatican.va (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_constitutions/documents/hf_jp-ii_apc_19901018_codex-can-eccl-orient-1_lt.html">official text</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110604154301/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_constitutions/documents/hf_jp-ii_apc_19901018_codex-can-eccl-orient-1_lt.html">Archived</a> 4 June 2011 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>). Intratext.com (English translation). 1990. Excerpt: "<i>Ritus est patrimonium liturgicum, theologicum, spirituale et disciplinare cultura ac rerum adiunctis historiae populorum distinctum, quod modo fidei vivendae uniuscuiusque Ecclesiae sui iuris proprio exprimitur</i>." (A rite is the liturgical, theological, spiritual and disciplinary heritage, differentiated by peoples' culture and historical circumstances, that finds expression in each <i>sui iuris</i> Church's own way of living the faith).</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-216">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150101045530/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG0015/__P41.HTM">"Catechism of the Catholic Church – IntraText – 1362–1364"</a>. <i>vatican.va</i>. <li id="cite_note-scborromeo.org-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-scborromeo.org_217-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scborromeo.org/ccc/para/1367.htm">"<i>CCC</i>,"</a>. scborromeo.org.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C&amp;rft.pub=scborromeo.org&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.scborromeo.org%2Fccc%2Fpara%2F1367.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-218"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-218">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Dobszay, Laszlo (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FYpD7C7__TYC&amp;pg=PA3">"3"</a>. <i>The Restoration and Organic Development of the Roman Rite</i>. New York: T&amp;T Clark International. pp.&#160;3–5. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-567-03385-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-567-03385-7"><bdi>978-0-567-03385-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=3&amp;rft.btitle=The+Restoration+and+Organic+Development+of+the+Roman+Rite&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=3-5&amp;rft.pub=T%26T+Clark+International&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-567-03385-7&amp;rft.aulast=Dobszay&amp;rft.aufirst=Laszlo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFYpD7C7&#95;_TYC%26pg%3DPA3&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-219">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/letters/2007/documents/hf_ben-xvi_let_20070707_lettera-vescovi_en.html">Letter of Pope Benedict XVI to bishops on 7 July 2007</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100929015429/http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/letters/2007/documents/hf_ben-xvi_let_20070707_lettera-vescovi_en.html">Archived</a> 29 September 2010 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> "The last version of the <i>Missale Romanum</i> prior to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Council</a>, which was published with the authority of Pope John XXIII in 1962 and used during the Council, will now be able to be used as a Forma extraordinaria of the liturgical celebration. [...] As for the use of the 1962 Missal as a <i>forma extraordinaria</i> of the liturgy of the Mass, I would like to draw attention to the fact that this Missal was never juridically abrogated and, consequently, in principle, was always permitted." — Pope Benedict XVI</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150521124654/http://www.liturgica.com/html/litWLEarly.jsp?hostname=null">"<i>Western Catholic Liturgics/Early Western Liturgics</i>"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.liturgica.com/html/litWLEarly.jsp?hostname=null#Worship">the original</a> on 21 May 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 March</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Western+Catholic+Liturgics%2FEarly+Western+Liturgics&amp;rft.pub=Liturgica.com&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.liturgica.com%2Fhtml%2FlitWLEarly.jsp%3Fhostname%3Dnull%23Worship&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-229"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-229">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.newadvent.org/library/docs_pi05qp.htm">"<i>Quo primum</i>"</a>. New Advent<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 March</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Quo+primum&amp;rft.pub=New+Advent&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.newadvent.org%2Flibrary%2Fdocs_pi05qp.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Fortescue, Adrian (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Eastern Churches"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Eastern_Churches">"Eastern Churches"&#160;</a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Eastern+Churches&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Fortescue&amp;rft.aufirst=Adrian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> See "Eastern Catholic Churches"; In part: "The definition of an Eastern-Rite Catholic is: A Christian of any <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Catholic churches">Eastern Catholic churches</a> in union with the pope: i.e. a Catholic who belongs not to the Roman, but to an Eastern rite. They differ from other Eastern Christians in that they are in communion with Rome, and from Latins in that they have other rites."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intratext.com/IXT/ENG1199/_P14.HTM">"<i>CCEO</i>, Canon 40"</a>. <li id="cite_note-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-234">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Delany, Joseph (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Corporal and Spiritual Works of Mercy"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Corporal_and_Spiritual_Works_of_Mercy">"Corporal and Spiritual Works of Mercy"&#160;</a></span>. <li id="cite_note-Compendium_of_the_CCC,_388-235"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Compendium_of_the_CCC,_388_235-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/compendium_ccc/documents/archive_2005_compendium-ccc_en.html#Mans%20Vocation:%20Life%20in%20the%20Spirit">"<i>Compendium of the CCC</i>, 388"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Cann22-236"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cann22_236-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160303192100/http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__PU.HTM">"Canon 222 §&#160;2"</a>. <i>1983 Code of Canon Law</i>. Vatican.va. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__PU.HTM">the original</a> on 3 March 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 February</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=1983+Code+of+Canon+Law&amp;rft.atitle=Canon+222+%C2%A7+2&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2FENG1104%2F&#95;_PU.HTM&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2337_-237"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2337_237-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p3s2c2a6.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 2337,2349"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>"People should cultivate [chastity] in the way that is suited to their state of life. Some profess virginity or consecrated celibacy which enables them to give themselves to God alone with an undivided heart in a remarkable manner. Others live in the way prescribed for all by the moral law, whether they are married or single." (CDF, <i><a href="/wiki/Persona_humana" class="mw-redirect" title="Persona humana">Persona humana</a></i> 11.) Married people are called to live conjugal chastity; others practise chastity in continence: "There are three forms of the virtue of chastity: the first is that of spouses, the second that of widows, and the third that of virgins. We do not praise any one of them to the exclusion of the others. ... This is what makes for the richness of the discipline of the Church." (St. Ambrose, De viduis 4,23:PL 16,255A.)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+2337%2C2349&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp3s2c2a6.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-NYT-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYT_238-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Yardley, Jim; Goodstein, Laurie (18 June 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/19/world/europe/pope-francis-in-sweeping-encyclical-calls-for-swift-action-on-climate-change.html">"Pope Francis, in Sweeping Encyclical, Calls for Swift Action on Climate Change"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Pope+Francis%2C+in+Sweeping+Encyclical%2C+Calls+for+Swift+Action+on+Climate+Change&amp;rft.date=2015-06-18&amp;rft.aulast=Yardley&amp;rft.aufirst=Jim&amp;rft.au=Goodstein%2C+Laurie&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2015%2F06%2F19%2Fworld%2Feurope%2Fpope-francis-in-sweeping-encyclical-calls-for-swift-action-on-climate-change.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-245"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-245">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vocations.com/womenrel.html">"Vocations Online Internet Directory of Women's Religious Communities"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Joliet_Diocese" class="mw-redirect" title="Joliet Diocese">Joliet Diocese</a> Vocation Office. 2010.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Vocations+Online+Internet+Directory+of+Women%27s+Religious+Communities&amp;rft.pub=Joliet+Diocese+Vocation+Office&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vocations.com%2Fwomenrel.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-249">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p3s2c2a6.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, Part 3, Section 2, Chapter 2, Article: The Sixth Commandment"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 November</span> 2014</span>. <q><b>2332:</b> Sexuality affects all aspects of the human person in the unity of his body and soul. It especially concerns affectivity, the capacity to love and to procreate, and in a more general way the aptitude for forming bonds of communion with others.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+Part+3%2C+Section+2%2C+Chapter+2%2C+Article%3A+The+Sixth+Commandment&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp3s2c2a6.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-253"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-253">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p3s2c2a6.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, "Conjugal fidelity": 2364–65; "The fecundity of marriage": 2366–72"</a>. <li id="cite_note-254"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-254">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">New York Times, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/20/world/europe/pope-bluntly-faults-churchs-focus-on-gays-and-abortion.html">Pope Says Church Is 'Obsessed' With Gays, Abortion and Birth Control</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-255"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-255">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">CNN, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://edition.cnn.com/2015/06/18/politics/pope-encyclical-climate-change-catholic-republicans/">Pope hands GOP climate change dilemma</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p2s2c3a7.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1640"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>Thus the marriage bond has been established by God himself in such a way that a marriage concluded and consummated between baptized persons can never be dissolved. This bond, which results from the free human act of the spouses and their consummation of the marriage, is a reality, henceforth irrevocable, and gives rise to a covenant guaranteed by God's fidelity. The Church does not have the power to contravene this disposition of divine wisdom. (Cf. <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canon_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Code of Canon Law">Code of Canon Law</a> 1983, can. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholicdoors.com/misc/marriage/canonlaw.htm">1141</a>)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1640&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp2s2c3a7.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-257"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-257">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/ccc_toc.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1625–1632"</a>. Vatican.va<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>For this reason (or for other reasons that render the marriage null and void) the Church, after an examination of the situation by the competent ecclesiastical tribunal, can declare the nullity of a marriage, i.e., that the marriage never existed. (Cf. <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canon_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Code of Canon Law">Code of Canon Law</a> 1983, cann. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholicdoors.com/misc/marriage/canonlaw.htm">1095–1107</a>)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1625%E2%80%931632&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fccc_toc.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-258"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-258">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p3s2c2a6.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 2384–86"</a>. <li id="cite_note-265"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-265">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A summary and restatement of the debate is available in Roderick Hindery. <li id="cite_note-cath_choice-266"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-cath_choice_266-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Catholics for a Choice (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20061011221417/http://www.catholicsforchoice.org/topics/prevention/documents/1998amatterofconsciece.pdf">"A Matter of Conscience: Catholics on Contraception"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Catholics for a Choice. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholicsforchoice.org/topics/prevention/documents/1998amatterofconsciece.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 11 October 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 October</span> 2006</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=A+Matter+of+Conscience%3A+Catholics+on+Contraception&amp;rft.pub=Catholics+for+a+Choice&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.au=Catholics+for+a+Choice&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.catholicsforchoice.org%2Ftopics%2Fprevention%2Fdocuments%2F1998amatterofconsciece.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-adherents-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-adherents_267-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.adherents.com/rel_USA.html">Largest Religious Groups in the USA</a>. Accessed 13 November 2005.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-cdc-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-cdc_268-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Chandra, A; Martinez GM; Mosher WD; Abma JC; Jones J. (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/series/sr_23/sr23_025.pdf">"Fertility, Family Planning, and Reproductive Health of U.S. Women: Data From the 2002 National Survey of Family Growth"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Vital and Health Statistics</i>. <li id="cite_note-CNS.AIDS-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CNS.AIDS_270-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://catholicleader.com.au/news/pope-speaks-out-on-condoms_45117">"Pope speaks out on condoms"</a>. <i>The Catholic Leader</i>. CNS. 29 March 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">27 March</span> 2017</span>. <q>Pope Benedict XVI's declaration that distribution of condoms only increases the problem of AIDS is the latest and one of the strongest statements in a simmering debate inside the church... he was asked whether the church's approach to AIDS prevention—which focuses primarily on sexual responsibility and rejects condom campaigns—was unrealistic and ineffective. ... The pope did not get into the specific question of whether in certain circumstances condom use was morally licit or illicit in AIDS prevention, an issue that is still under study by Vatican theologians.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Catholic+Leader&amp;rft.atitle=Pope+speaks+out+on+condoms&amp;rft.date=2009-03-29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fcatholicleader.com.au%2Fnews%2Fpope-speaks-out-on-condoms_45117&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/ccc_css/archive/catechism/p2s1.htm">"<i>CCC</i>, 1076"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>§&#160;1076: The Church was made manifest to the world on the day of Pentecost by the outpouring of the Holy Spirit....</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=CCC%2C+1076&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fccc_css%2Farchive%2Fcatechism%2Fp2s1.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> </span>

<li id="cite_note-292"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-292">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Herbermann, Charles, ed. (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/Holy Ghost"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/Holy_Ghost">"Holy Ghost"&#160;</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. With these Apostles He will abide for ever (John 14:16). Having descended on them at Pentecost, He will guide them in their work (Acts 8:29)...</span>

<li id="cite_note-JoyceCE1913-297"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-JoyceCE1913_297-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-JoyceCE1913_297-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Joyce, George (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/The Pope"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/The_Pope">"The Pope"&#160;</a></span>.  In Herbermann, Charles (ed.). <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. New York: Robert Appleton Company.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Pope&amp;rft.btitle=Catholic+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=Robert+Appleton+Company&amp;rft.date=1913&amp;rft.aulast=Joyce&amp;rft.aufirst=George&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-299"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-299">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161212105950/http://www.catholic.com/tracts/was-peter-in-rome">"Was Peter in Rome?"</a>. Catholic Answers. 10 August 2004. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.catholic.com/tracts/was-peter-in-rome">the original</a> on 12 December 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">9 November</span> 2014</span>. <q>if Peter never made it to the capital, he still could have been the first pope, since one of his successors could have been the first holder of that office to settle in Rome. After all, if the papacy exists, it was established by Christ during his lifetime, long before Peter is said to have reached Rome. There must have been a period of some years in which the papacy did not yet have its connection to Rome.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Was+Peter+in+Rome%3F&amp;rft.pub=Catholic+Answers&amp;rft.date=2004-08-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.catholic.com%2Ftracts%2Fwas-peter-in-rome&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-REB-300"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-REB_300-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-REB_300-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-REB_300-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Raymond E. Brown, <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=b8ubeFP6JUYC&amp;pg=PA134&amp;dq=Peter+symbolisms+attached#v=onepage&amp;q=Peter%20symbolisms%20attached">101 Questions and Answers on the Bible</a></i> (Paulist Press 2003 <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-4251-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8091-4251-4">978-0-8091-4251-4</a>), pp. 132–134</span>

<li id="cite_note-ehrman-303"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ehrman_303-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Ehrman, Bart D (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://global.oup.com/academic/product/peter-paul-and-mary-magdalene-9780195343502"><i>Peter, Paul, and Mary Magdalene: The Followers of Jesus in History and Legend</i></a>. US: Oxford University Press. p.&#160;84. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-530013-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-530013-0"><bdi>978-0-19-530013-0</bdi></a>. <q>Peter, in short, could not have been the first bishop of Rome, because the Roman church did not have <i>anyone</i> as its bishop until about a hundred years after Peter's death.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Peter%2C+Paul%2C+and+Mary+Magdalene%3A+The+Followers+of+Jesus+in+History+and+Legend&amp;rft.place=US&amp;rft.pages=84&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-530013-0&amp;rft.aulast=Ehrman&amp;rft.aufirst=Bart+D&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fglobal.oup.com%2Facademic%2Fproduct%2Fpeter-paul-and-mary-magdalene-9780195343502&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-311">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Ayer, Joseph Cullen, Jr. (1913). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=u1gMAAAAIAAJ&amp;pg=PA538"><i>A Source Book for Ancient Church History: From the Apostolic Age to the Close of the Conciliar Period</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-313"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-313">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Baumgartner, Frederic J. (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=UzGEppDeP8gC&amp;pg=PA10"><i>Behind Locked Doors: A History of the Papal Elections</i></a>. Palgrave Macmillan. pp.&#160;10–12. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-312-29463-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-312-29463-2"><bdi>978-0-312-29463-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Behind+Locked+Doors%3A+A+History+of+the+Papal+Elections&amp;rft.pages=10-12&amp;rft.pub=Palgrave+Macmillan&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-312-29463-2&amp;rft.aulast=Baumgartner&amp;rft.aufirst=Frederic+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUzGEppDeP8gC%26pg%3DPA10&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-314"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-314">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Eamon_Duffy" title="Eamon Duffy">Duffy, Eamon</a>. 1997. <i>Saints &amp; Sinners: A History of the Popes</i>. Yale University Press. pp. 66–67</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-315"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-315">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Le Goff, p. 14: "The face of the barbarian invaders had been transformed by another crucial fact. Although some of them had remained pagan, another part of them, not the least, had become Christian. But, by a curious chance, which was to leave serious consequences, these converted barbarians—the Ostrogoths, Visigoths, Burgundians, Vandals, and later the Lombards—had been converted to Arianism, which had become a heresy after the council of Nicaea. They had in fact been converted by followers of the 'apostle of the Goths', Wulfilas."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-316"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-316">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Le Goff, p. 14: "Thus what should have been a religious bond was, on the contrary, a subject of discord and sparked off bitter conflicts between Arian barbarians and Catholic Romans."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-317"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-317">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Le Goff, p. 21: "Clovis' master-stroke was to convert himself and his people not to Arianism, like the other barbarian kings, but to Catholicism."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-318"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-318">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Le Goff, p. 21</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-319"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-319">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Drew, Katherine Fischer (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=7ItMSn421GAC&amp;pg=PR18"><i>The Lombard Laws</i></a>. University of Pennsylvania Press. p.&#160;xviii. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8122-1055-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8122-1055-2"><bdi>978-0-8122-1055-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Lombard+Laws&amp;rft.pages=xviii&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Pennsylvania+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8122-1055-2&amp;rft.aulast=Drew&amp;rft.aufirst=Katherine+Fischer&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D7ItMSn421GAC%26pg%3DPR18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-320"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-320">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>How The Irish Saved Civilization: The Untold Story of Ireland's Heroic Role from the Fall of Rome to the Rise of Medieval Europe</i> by Thomas Cahill, 1995.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-324"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-324">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Pirenne, Henri (1980) [1925]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=TKUN4UdfVaQC&amp;pg=PA27"><i>Medieval Cities: Their Origins and the Revival of Trade</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-325">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Richards, Jeffrey (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Zod9AwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA230"><i>The Popes and the Papacy in the Early Middle Ages</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-326"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-326">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Walker, Willston (1985). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=bFw8PtQhpVoC&amp;pg=PA251"><i>History of the Christian Church</i></a>. Simon and Schuster. pp.&#160;250–251. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-684-18417-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-684-18417-3"><bdi>978-0-684-18417-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+the+Christian+Church&amp;rft.pages=250-251&amp;rft.pub=Simon+and+Schuster&amp;rft.date=1985&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-684-18417-3&amp;rft.aulast=Walker&amp;rft.aufirst=Willston&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DbFw8PtQhpVoC%26pg%3DPA251&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Vidmar107-327"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Vidmar107_327-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Vidmar, <i>The Catholic Church Through the Ages</i> (2005), pp. 107–11</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Duffy78-328"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Duffy78_328-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Duffy, <i>Saints and Sinners</i> (1997), p. 78, quote: "By contrast, Paschal's successor <a href="/wiki/Pope_Eugene_II" title="Pope Eugene II">Eugenius II</a> (824–7), elected with imperial influence, gave away most of these papal gains. He acknowledged the Emperor's sovereignty in the papal state, and he accepted a constitution imposed by Lothair which established imperial supervision of the administration of Rome, imposed an oath to the Emperor on all citizens, and required the pope–elect to swear fealty before he could be consecrated. Under <a href="/wiki/Pope_Sergius_II" title="Pope Sergius II">Sergius II</a> (844–7) it was even agreed that the pope could not be consecrated without an imperial mandate, and that the ceremony must be in the presence of his representative, a revival of some of the more galling restrictions of Byzantine rule."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-rileysmith-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-rileysmith_329-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Riley-Smith, p. 8</span>

<li id="cite_note-354"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-354">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><img alt="Wikisource-logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="13" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="430" />&#160;<cite class="citation encyclopaedia">Herbermann, Charles, ed. (1913). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="Wikisource:Catholic Encyclopedia (1913)/The Sixteen Blessed Teresian Martyrs of Compiègne"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia_(1913)/The_Sixteen_Blessed_Teresian_Martyrs_of_Compi%C3%A8gne">"The Sixteen Blessed Teresian Martyrs of Compiègne"&#160;</a></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Encyclopedia" title="Catholic Encyclopedia">Catholic Encyclopedia</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-388">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080221180735/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19631204_sacrosanctum-concilium_en.html">"Constitution on the Sacred Liturgy Sacrosanctum Concilium"</a>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19631204_sacrosanctum-concilium_en.html">the original</a> on 21 February 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 January</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Constitution+on+the+Sacred+Liturgy+Sacrosanctum+Concilium&amp;rft.pub=Vatican.va&amp;rft.date=1963-12-04&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.vatican.va%2Farchive%2Fhist_councils%2Fii_vatican_council%2Fdocuments%2Fvat-ii_const_19631204_sacrosanctum-concilium_en.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ACatholic+Church" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-Duffy272-389"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Duffy272_389-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Duffy, pp. 270–276</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-390">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Duffy, <i>Saints and Sinners</i> (1997), pp. 272, 274</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-NOSTRA_AETATE-391"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NOSTRA_AETATE_391-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Pope Paul VI. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_decl_19651028_nostra-aetate_en.html"><i>Nostra aetate</i>: Declaration on the Relation of the Church to Non-Christian Religions</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20081220214550/http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_decl_19651028_nostra-aetate_en.html">Archived</a> 20 December 2008 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>. 28 October 1965. Retrieved 16 June 2011. According to Section 4: "True, the Jewish authorities and those who followed their lead pressed for the death of Christ; still, what happened in His passion cannot be charged against all the Jews, without distinction, then alive, nor against the Jews of today. Although the Church is the new people of God, the Jews should not be presented as rejected or accursed by God, as if this followed from the Holy Scriptures."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-392"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-392">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bauckham, p. 373</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-414"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-414">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Echeverria, Eduardo (17 October 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.crisismagazine.com/2014/synods-interim-report-ambiguity-misinterpretation">"The Synod's Interim Report: Ambiguity and Misinterpretation"</a>, <i>Crisis Magazine</i>.</span>

The Essential Catholic Catechism.Servant Publications. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-56955-128-6" title="Special:BookSources/1-56955-128-6">1-56955-128-6</a>.</li>

<li>Stewart, Cynthia (2008) <i>The Catholic Church: A Brief Popular History</i> 337 pages</li>

Available at <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/75243/1/MPRA_paper_75243.pdf">https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/75243/1/MPRA_paper_75243.pdf</a> <a href="/wiki/Research_Papers_in_Economics" title="Research Papers in Economics">IDEAS/RePEc</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a></li>
<li>Tausch, Arno, The Effects of 'Nostra Aetate:' Comparative Analyses of Catholic Antisemitism More Than Five Decades after the Second Vatican Council (8 January 2018). Available at SSRN: <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="https://ssrn.com/abstract=3098079">https://ssrn.com/abstract=3098079</a></li>

Libreria Editrice Vaticana. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-88-209-7908-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-88-209-7908-9">978-88-209-7908-9</a>.</li>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Francis</a> as <a href="/wiki/Bishop_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Bishop in the Catholic Church">bishop</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Diocese of Rome</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Papal_primacy" title="Papal primacy">Primacy</a></li></ul></li></ul>
</div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th id="Vatican_City_(Index,_Outline)" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="background-color:gold;width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> <small>(<a href="/wiki/Index_of_Vatican_City-related_articles" title="Index of Vatican City-related articles">Index</a>, <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Vatican_City" title="Outline of Vatican City">Outline</a>)</small></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Enclaved" class="mw-redirect" title="Enclaved">enclaved</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaty" title="Lateran Treaty">Lateran Treaty</a> 1929</li></ul></li>
<li>along with <a href="/wiki/Extraterritoriality" title="Extraterritoriality">extraterritorial</a> <a href="/wiki/Properties_of_the_Holy_See" title="Properties of the Holy See">properties of the Holy See</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>

<li><a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_F%C3%A1tima" title="Our Lady of Fátima">Our Lady of Fátima</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_and_Pius_XII" title="Persecutions of the Catholic Church and Pius XII">Persecutions of the Catholic Church and Pius XII</a></li>
